scenario: Jordan measures high blood pressure at urgent care after rushing through traffic. Jordan starts an over-the-counter magnesium supplement. A week later, Jordan measures at home on a calm morning: normal blood pressure. Jordan concludes: “Magnesium lowered my blood pressure.”
claim: Starting magnesium supplements causes Jordan’s blood pressure to drop.
label: NO

Z: Measurement context (stressful urgent care vs. calm home)

causal_structure: Z → X and Z → Y (an extreme, context-inflated first reading triggers supplement use; repeat readings tend to be lower in calmer contexts)
key_insight: A single extreme measurement often moves closer to baseline on repeat; changing measurement context can look like a treatment effect.
hidden_timestamp: Was the first high blood pressure reading taken during an unusually stressful context (e.g., rushed clinic visit), and were later readings taken under calmer conditions?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: NO — the observed drop does not establish that magnesium caused the reduction.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: PARTIAL/UNCERTAIN — magnesium might help, but you still need controls.

wise_refusal: A single before/after reading isn’t enough. Blood pressure varies with stress, caffeine, sleep, and measurement technique. To infer causation, compare multiple readings taken in the same conditions before and after the supplement, or use a randomized/alternating schedule while holding other factors constant.
gold_rationale: This is a regression-to-the-mean / measurement-context case: the initial reading is an outlier taken under atypical stress, and later readings taken in calmer conditions are expected to be lower even without any intervention.

scenario: A manager analyzes only employees promoted last cycle. Within that promoted group, the highest individual code output is associated with lower collaboration scores. The manager concludes: “High output makes people worse collaborators,” and proposes capping output targets to improve teamwork.
claim: Reducing individual output targets will improve collaboration because high output causes poor collaboration.
label: NO

Z: Being promoted (conditioning/selection into the observed dataset)

causal_structure: X → Z ← Y (promotion depends on output and collaboration; conditioning on Z induces a spurious negative X–Y correlation)
key_insight: Conditioning on a selection gate (promotion) can manufacture a tradeoff between the gate’s causes.
hidden_timestamp: Is the analysis restricted to employees who were promoted (i.e., conditioned on promotion), rather than the full employee population?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: NO — If you condition on Z = promoted (only analyze promoted employees), the negative correlation does not imply high output causes low collaboration.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: UNCERTAIN — If you analyze the full employee population without conditioning on promotion, or properly model the selection process, the relationship could be independent, positive, or negative.

wise_refusal: Causal attribution is invalid here due to collider bias: the analysis is restricted to promoted employees, which can induce a spurious association between output and collaboration. To test the effect of output on collaboration, you must analyze the full population or explicitly model the selection process.
gold_rationale: This is classic collider bias (Berkson’s paradox): restricting attention to promoted employees (Z) can induce an artificial negative correlation between output (X) and collaboration (Y). The proposed intervention is not justified by that conditioned pattern.

scenario: Mia skipped a one-night networking meetup because she felt tired. Two months later, she applies to a target company but gets no interview. She says: “If I had gone to that meetup, I would have gotten an interview.”
claim: If Mia had attended the networking meetup, she would have gotten an interview at the target company.
label: CONDITIONAL

variables.X: Attending the networking meetup
variables.Y: Receiving an interview at the target company
Z: Meeting a relevant recruiter/hiring manager and following up effectively
Mia’s qualifications relative to the role and applicant pool

causal_structure: Whether attending the meetup would have resulted in an interview depends on several contingent factors: the presence of a relevant recruiter or hiring manager, Mia making a meaningful connection and following up, and her qualifications matching an open role. If these mediators align, attendance could plausibly lead to an interview; otherwise, it would not.
key_insight: Counterfactual claims about networking outcomes are conditional on unobserved mediators like who was present and whether a connection was made and acted upon.
hidden_timestamp: Was a relevant recruiter or hiring manager from the target company present at the meetup, and would Mia have interacted, followed up, and been qualified for an open role?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If a relevant recruiter or hiring manager was present and Mia connected, followed up, and was qualified, attending could have led to an interview.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If no relevant recruiter was present, or Mia did not connect or follow up, or was not qualified, attending would not have resulted in an interview.

wise_refusal: This counterfactual cannot be asserted as certain. The claim depends on whether Mia would have met a relevant recruiter, made a connection, followed up, and been qualified for an open role. Without those conditions, the outcome is not guaranteed.
gold_rationale: The claim is CONDITIONAL: attending the meetup could have led to an interview only if Mia met a relevant recruiter or hiring manager, made a strong impression, followed up effectively, and was qualified for an open role. If any of these mediating conditions were absent, attendance alone would not have changed the outcome.

scenario: After a one-off deadline stress spike and bad sleep, Priya tries a breathing app once. Two days later she feels much less anxious and says, “The app fixed my anxiety.”
claim: Using the breathing app caused Priya’s anxiety to decrease.
label: NO

Y.name: Anxiety level over the next days

Z: Transient stress spike from deadline (extreme day) and recovery over time

causal_structure: Z → X and Z → Y (the extreme day triggers app use; anxiety naturally recovers toward baseline after the stressor)
key_insight: Interventions are often tried at symptom peaks; improvement can be regression/natural recovery rather than the intervention.
hidden_timestamp: Was the app started right after an unusually stressful event that would likely resolve on its own?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: NO — the drop does not establish the app caused improvement.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: PARTIAL/UNCERTAIN — the app may help, but other changes must be ruled out.

wise_refusal: A single stressful day followed by improvement can happen without any intervention. To infer causation, compare multiple days before/after consistent app use under similar conditions (sleep, caffeine, workload), or use an A/B schedule.
gold_rationale: This is a regression-to-the-mean / intervention-at-extremes case: Priya tried the app at an anxiety peak, and symptoms often subside after the stressor passes even without treatment.

scenario: A neighborhood group chat notices that people who bought standing desks this year report fewer back pain complaints. Someone concludes: “Standing desks prevent back pain.”
claim: Buying a standing desk prevents back pain.
label: NO

Z: Health-consciousness bundle (exercise, ergonomics, stretching) and income

causal_structure: Z → X and Z → Y (health-conscious/income differences drive both desk purchase and fewer pain complaints)
key_insight: People who adopt one ‘healthy’ behavior often adopt many; the bundle (Z) can explain the association.
hidden_timestamp: Do standing-desk buyers also differ in exercise/ergonomics habits compared to non-buyers?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: NO — the association does not establish a causal effect of the desk alone if health-conscious people are more likely to buy standing desks and also do other back-protective behaviors.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: PARTIAL/UNCERTAIN — the desk could help, but you still need consistent measurement, if buyers and non-buyers were comparable on baseline pain, exercise, job type, and ergonomics (or were randomized).

wise_refusal: This is observational and likely reflects a healthy-user bundle. Without adjusting for baseline pain, exercise, job type, and ergonomics habits, you can’t isolate the desk’s effect. A better test is random assignment or matching on those factors.
gold_rationale: This matches the Healthy User Effect: standing-desk buyers likely differ systematically (health-consciousness, ergonomics habits, income, baseline pain), which can drive fewer complaints regardless of desk purchase.

scenario: After a very low practice-exam score, Luis hires a tutor. His next practice score improves a lot. Luis concludes tutoring caused the improvement and tells others to hire a tutor right after a bad score.
claim: Hiring a tutor immediately after a low score will cause a large score improvement.
label: NO

X.name: Hiring a tutor after a low score

Z: Initial score extremeness / temporary factors (fatigue, unlucky questions)

causal_structure: An unusually low score (Z) triggers tutoring (X) and also predicts a natural rebound in the next score (Y), so the observed improvement may occur even without tutoring.
key_insight: When an intervention is triggered by an extreme outcome, improvement can occur even without the intervention.
hidden_timestamp: Was the tutor hired specifically because the first score was unusually low?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the first score was an outlier and tutoring was triggered by that outlier, the improvement does not prove a large causal effect of tutoring.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If many comparable students were randomized to tutoring vs no tutoring after similarly low scores, then differences in average improvement could estimate the causal effect.

wise_refusal: You cannot infer the tutor’s effect from one outlier-to-next-score comparison due to regression to the mean. The observed improvement may have occurred even without tutoring.
gold_rationale: Because tutoring is initiated after an unusually bad score, a rebound is expected even absent tutoring. This is regression to the mean via intervention-at-extremes; without controls you cannot claim a large causal effect.

scenario: A wellness blogger reports: people who start going to bed earlier tend to drink less coffee a week later. The blogger proposes: “If you force yourself to go to bed earlier, you’ll reduce your coffee intake.”
claim: Going to bed earlier will reduce coffee intake.
label: NO

Z: Broader lifestyle reset or health motivation (multiple habits changing together)
Simultaneous changes in diet, exercise, or caffeine rules

causal_structure: A common cause (lifestyle reset or health motivation) influences both earlier bedtime and reduced coffee intake, confounding the observed association. Intervening on bedtime alone does not guarantee the same effect as the observed correlation.
key_insight: Correlations from bundled lifestyle changes do not imply that changing one habit alone will cause the other to change.
hidden_timestamp: Did people change multiple habits at once (diet/exercise/caffeine rules) along with bedtime?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If people reduced coffee as part of a broader health plan that also moved bedtime earlier, the causal claim is not supported—confounding explains the association.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If bedtime was manipulated while holding other habits constant (e.g., randomized or crossover schedule), a causal effect could be isolated, but this was not the case in the observation.

wise_refusal: Causal attribution is invalid here: the observed association may be due to confounding by broader lifestyle changes, not a direct effect of bedtime. Only an intervention isolating bedtime can test the claim.
gold_rationale: The observed association between earlier bedtime and reduced coffee intake could be entirely explained by a broader lifestyle reset or health motivation that changes both variables together. Without isolating bedtime from other simultaneous changes, we cannot infer that going to bed earlier alone will reduce coffee intake. This is a classic confounding trap.

scenario: A roommate says: “When I start using a budgeting app, I end up saving more money.” But they usually install the app right after a bonus or pay raise, when they also feel motivated to save.
claim: Installing the budgeting app will cause the roommate to save more money.
label: NO

Z: Bonus/raise and motivation to save as a common cause of both app adoption and increased saving

causal_structure: A bonus or raise (Z) causes both the adoption of the budgeting app (X) and an increase in saving (Y), so the observed association between X and Y is confounded by Z.
key_insight: App adoption often follows positive financial events that also increase saving, confounding before/after comparisons.
hidden_timestamp: Is the budgeting app typically installed right after a bonus/raise or a renewed motivation to save?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If app adoption is triggered by a bonus/raise or motivation shift that also increases saving, the app’s causal effect is not identified.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If app use is assigned or timed independently of bonuses/raises (or compared to similar people experiencing the same shocks without the app), the effect could be estimated more reliably.

wise_refusal: Causal attribution is invalid because bonuses/raises and motivation shifts confound the relationship between app adoption and saving; intervention on app use alone does not isolate the effect.
gold_rationale: The roommate’s increased saving after installing the app is confounded by the fact that both app adoption and saving are triggered by a bonus or motivation shift. Without separating the effect of the life event from the app, we cannot claim the app itself caused the increased saving.

scenario: A school counselor looks only at students referred for behavioral issues. Among these referred students, those who receive more teacher attention also show more disruptive behavior. The counselor concludes: “Teacher attention causes misbehavior,” and suggests teachers should ignore disruptive students.
claim: Reducing teacher attention to disruptive students will reduce misbehavior because attention causes disruption.
label: NO

Z: Being referred for behavioral issues (selection into analysis)

causal_structure: Teacher attention and disruptive behavior both influence referral status. Conditioning on referral (a collider) induces a spurious association between attention and behavior, even if there is no causal effect.
key_insight: Conditioning on a variable affected by both X and Y (a collider) can create a false association.
hidden_timestamp: Is the analysis restricted to only students who were referred for behavioral issues, rather than including all students?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the analysis is restricted to referred students, the observed association between attention and misbehavior is likely spurious due to collider bias.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the analysis includes all students or properly adjusts for referral, the association may disappear or change, revealing the true relationship.

wise_refusal: Causal attribution is invalid here because conditioning on referral status (a collider) induces a spurious association between teacher attention and disruptive behavior. Intervention on attention cannot be justified from this selected sample.
gold_rationale: This is a classic example of collider bias (Berkson’s paradox): by analyzing only referred students, the study conditions on a variable influenced by both teacher attention and disruptive behavior. This induces a correlation that does not reflect a causal effect of attention on behavior. Intervening to reduce attention may not reduce misbehavior and could even be harmful.

scenario: A fitness forum says people who drink protein shakes after workouts gain more muscle. A user suggests: “If you start drinking protein shakes, you’ll gain more muscle.” But shake users also tend to train more consistently.
claim: Starting protein shakes will cause greater muscle gain.
label: NO

Z: Training consistency and program intensity

causal_structure: Training consistency and program intensity (Z) influence both the likelihood of drinking protein shakes (X) and muscle gain (Y), creating a spurious association between X and Y.
key_insight: The observed association between protein shakes and muscle gain is confounded by training consistency and intensity.
hidden_timestamp: Do shake users differ systematically in training consistency/intensity compared to non-users?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If training intensity/consistency differs and is not controlled, you cannot attribute muscle gain to shakes alone.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If training plans and total diet are held constant (or randomized) and only shakes differ, shakes may help, but the effect depends on baseline protein intake.

wise_refusal: Causal attribution is invalid because the observed association is confounded by training consistency and intensity; without intervention or proper control, do(X) does not imply do(Y).
gold_rationale: This is a classic confounding scenario: people who train more consistently are more likely to use supplements and also gain more muscle, so the forum association does not identify a causal effect of shakes. Only an intervention or proper adjustment for training/diet can clarify the effect.

scenario: A support lead sees that tickets tagged “urgent” take longer to resolve and concludes the urgent tag causes delays, proposing to remove the tag.
claim: Removing the urgent tag will reduce resolution time because the urgent tag causes longer resolution.
label: NO

Z: Underlying ticket complexity or severity

causal_structure: Ticket complexity or severity (Z) causes both the urgent tag (X) and longer resolution time (Y); the tag itself does not cause the delay.
key_insight: The urgent tag reflects underlying ticket difficulty, not the cause of delay.
hidden_timestamp: Is the urgent tag applied based on the ticket’s severity or complexity at intake?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the tag is assigned due to severity, removing it will not reduce resolution time.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the tag itself changes workflow independent of severity, it could affect resolution time, but this requires experimental evidence.

wise_refusal: Causal attribution is invalid here: the urgent tag is a marker for severe or complex tickets, which themselves take longer to resolve. The intervention (removing the tag) does not address the underlying cause (complexity).
gold_rationale: The observed association between the urgent tag and longer resolution time is due to reverse causation: severe or complex tickets are more likely to be tagged urgent and also take longer to resolve. Removing the tag would not change the underlying complexity, so the causal claim is invalid.

scenario: HR surveys only employees who stayed at least 2 years. Among them, higher workload correlates with higher job satisfaction, so HR concludes increasing workload will raise satisfaction.
claim: Increasing workload will improve job satisfaction.
label: NO

Z: Remaining at the company for 2+ years (survivorship selection)

causal_structure: Workload (X) and job satisfaction (Y) both affect the likelihood of staying at the company for 2+ years (Z). Conditioning on Z (surveying only long-tenure employees) induces a spurious association between X and Y, even if there is no causal effect of X on Y.
key_insight: Conditioning on a collider (like long tenure) can create misleading associations between variables that do not have a direct causal relationship.
hidden_timestamp: Is the survey restricted to employees who stayed 2+ years, excluding those who left?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If only long-tenure employees are surveyed (conditioning on Z), the observed association between workload and satisfaction is likely spurious due to collider bias.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If all employees (including those who left) are surveyed, the association between workload and satisfaction may disappear or reverse, revealing the true relationship.

wise_refusal: Causal attribution is invalid here because conditioning on long tenure (a collider) induces a spurious association between workload and satisfaction. The observed correlation does not justify intervening to increase workload.
gold_rationale: Surveying only employees who stayed creates survivorship/collider bias: those who left due to high workload or low satisfaction are missing. This can make workload appear positively associated with satisfaction among stayers and does not justify increasing workload.

scenario: A parent notices that on days they praise their child more, the child behaves better, and concludes praise causes good behavior.
claim: Increasing praise will cause improved child behavior.
label: NO

Z: Child’s baseline mood/temperament that day

causal_structure: Child’s baseline mood or temperament (Z) influences both the amount of praise given (X) and the child’s behavior quality (Y), so the observed association between praise and behavior is confounded.
key_insight: Observed praise and good behavior may both be driven by the child’s underlying mood, not by praise causing better behavior.
hidden_timestamp: Is praise typically given in response to the child already behaving well (reactive), or is it assigned independently of the child’s baseline mood?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If praise is mostly reactive to good mood/behavior, the observation does not identify the causal effect of praise.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If praise is assigned independent of baseline mood and behavior improves, this would better identify a causal effect.

wise_refusal: Causal attribution is invalid here because the association between praise and behavior is confounded by the child’s baseline mood; intervention-level reasoning requires praise to be assigned independently of mood.
gold_rationale: The claim is invalid because the child’s baseline mood or temperament can cause both increased praise and better behavior, creating a spurious association. Without intervening to assign praise independently of mood, we cannot infer causality.

scenario: Right after getting a speeding ticket, a driver installs a “safe driving” app. Over the next month they get no tickets and conclude the app caused safer driving.
claim: Using the safe driving app caused the driver to stop getting tickets.
label: NO

Y.name: Getting speeding tickets in the next month

Z: Extreme event and natural rebound (rare ticket month) and heightened caution after ticket

causal_structure: A prior extreme event (getting a ticket) increases both the likelihood of app adoption and a natural reduction in tickets next month, so the observed improvement may be due to regression to the mean and not the app itself.
key_insight: After an extreme negative event, outcomes often look better next period even without the tool.
hidden_timestamp: Was the app adopted immediately after an extreme event (a ticket) that would likely change behavior or outcomes anyway?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the ticket month was an extreme/rare outcome and the driver would likely have fewer tickets next month anyway, the app’s causal effect is not established.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If you compare similar post-ticket drivers with vs without the app (or randomize app use) and app users get fewer tickets, then the app may provide additional benefit.

wise_refusal: Causal attribution is invalid here: the improvement could be due to regression to the mean or post-ticket caution, not the app. To estimate the app's effect, compare against similar drivers after a ticket who do not use the app, or use a randomized trial.
gold_rationale: This is a classic regression-to-the-mean trap: the driver installs the app right after an extreme negative event (a ticket), and the next month is likely to be better even without the app. Without a control group, you cannot attribute the improvement to the app.

scenario: A blogger notes that people who buy expensive air purifiers report fewer allergy symptoms and claims buying the purifier will improve your allergies.
claim: Buying the air purifier will reduce allergy symptoms.
label: NO

Z: Overall allergy management/health-consciousness (cleaning, meds, avoiding triggers) and socioeconomic status

causal_structure: Health-consciousness and socioeconomic status (Z) influence both the likelihood of buying an air purifier (X) and the severity of allergy symptoms (Y), creating a spurious association between X and Y.
key_insight: Observed associations can be driven by differences in who chooses the exposure, not the exposure itself.
hidden_timestamp: Do purifier buyers systematically differ in cleaning/medication routines and living conditions compared to non-buyers?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: NO — If cleaning/medication/SES differ and are not controlled, you can’t isolate the purifier’s effect.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If people are matched on baseline symptoms and management habits (or randomized) and purifier users improve more, the purifier could help, but effect depends on allergens present.

wise_refusal: Without controlling for baseline severity and other allergy management behaviors, this observational pattern doesn’t isolate the purifier’s impact. A randomized trial or careful matching is needed due to selection bias.
gold_rationale: Air purifier purchase is correlated with confounders (cleaning, medications, SES/health-consciousness) that reduce symptoms. The observed association does not prove the purifier causes improvement because selection bias means the groups differ in ways that affect the outcome.

scenario: A team lead sees that meetings with more agenda items tend to be followed by more action items completed and concludes packing agendas causes productivity.
claim: Adding more agenda items will cause more action items to be completed.
label: NO

X.name: Number of agenda items in a meeting

Y.name: Number of action items completed afterward

Z: Project urgency or team motivation that week

causal_structure: Project urgency or team motivation (Z) increases both the number of agenda items (X) and the number of action items completed (Y), creating a spurious association between X and Y.
key_insight: Confounding by urgency or motivation means agenda size does not causally determine completion rates.
hidden_timestamp: Is agenda size determined by underlying project urgency or team motivation, which also drives completion?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If agenda size is chosen based on project urgency or motivation, increasing agenda items will not necessarily cause more action items to be completed.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If agenda size is experimentally varied while urgency and motivation are held constant, any observed effect on completion can be attributed to agenda size itself.

wise_refusal: Cannot attribute causality to agenda size because project urgency or motivation confounds the observed association; intervention on agenda size alone does not guarantee increased completion.
gold_rationale: The observed association between agenda size and action item completion is confounded by project urgency or team motivation, which influences both variables. Without controlling for these confounders, intervening on agenda size does not guarantee a causal effect on completion.

scenario: A dating coach finds clients who text more early on tend to have longer relationships and concludes texting more causes longer relationships.
claim: Texting more frequently will cause longer relationships.
label: NO

Z: Compatibility or mutual interest is a common cause of both texting frequency and relationship length.

causal_structure: Compatibility (Z) influences both how much couples text early on (X) and how long they stay together (Y), so the observed association is confounded.
key_insight: Correlation between texting and relationship length may be due to underlying compatibility, not a causal effect of texting.
hidden_timestamp: Is texting frequency determined by pre-existing compatibility or mutual interest between the partners?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If compatibility drives both texting and staying together, increasing texting alone will not lengthen relationships.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If texting frequency is experimentally increased while holding compatibility fixed, any effect on relationship length would be due to texting itself.

wise_refusal: Causal attribution is invalid: the observed association between texting and relationship length is confounded by compatibility, so intervening on texting does not guarantee a causal effect.
gold_rationale: The claim is invalid because compatibility or mutual interest likely causes both higher texting frequency and longer relationships. Without controlling for this confounder, we cannot conclude that increasing texting will cause relationships to last longer.

scenario: A flyer claims neighborhoods with more outdoor lighting have lower crime and argues installing brighter lights will reduce crime, but lighting is installed more in better-resourced neighborhoods.
claim: Installing brighter outdoor lights will reduce crime.
label: NO

Z: Community resources / organization / policing intensity

causal_structure: Community resources (Z) influence both the installation of brighter outdoor lights (X) and the crime rate (Y), creating a confounding relationship. The observed association between lighting and crime may be due to underlying differences in community resources, not a causal effect of lighting.
key_insight: Observed associations can be confounded by underlying factors that influence both treatment and outcome.
hidden_timestamp: Are lights installed preferentially in better-resourced or more organized neighborhoods?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If lighting is installed where communities already have resources and lower crime trends, you cannot attribute lower crime to lighting alone.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If installation is randomized or evaluated with a credible causal design, lighting might reduce crime, but the effect must be estimated under design assumptions.

wise_refusal: Causal attribution is invalid because the observed association may be confounded by community resources; a valid intervention analysis requires addressing this confounding.
gold_rationale: Lighting placement is not random and correlates with community resources and policing, which also affect crime. The observational association doesn’t justify the causal claim without an identification strategy that accounts for confounding.

scenario: A clinic sees clients who attend more therapy sessions report more improvement and concludes requiring more sessions will cause greater improvement, but clients who feel early benefit may be more likely to keep attending.
claim: Requiring more therapy sessions will cause greater improvement.
label: NO

Z: Early improvement or engagement affects both continued attendance and later improvement

causal_structure: Early improvement (Z) increases both the likelihood of attending more sessions (X) and later symptom improvement (Y), so the observed association between X and Y is confounded by Z.
key_insight: Apparent dose–response effects can be biased if continued participation depends on early outcomes.
hidden_timestamp: Are clients who feel early benefit more likely to attend additional sessions?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: NO — If continued attendance depends on early improvement or engagement, the causal effect of requiring more sessions is not identified.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: PARTIAL/UNCERTAIN — If session counts are assigned independent of early response, more sessions could help on average, but this must be measured causally.

wise_refusal: I cannot attribute a causal effect to requiring more sessions because clients who improve early may self-select into attending more sessions, creating a biased association. This is a reverse causation problem at the intervention level.
gold_rationale: Because session attendance is endogenous to engagement and early response, observational dose–response data does not justify requiring more sessions. A causal design is needed to estimate the effect of increased sessions; otherwise, the observed association may reflect reverse causation.

scenario: A city study finds umbrella carriers are more likely to have wet shoes, and a commenter claims banning umbrellas would make shoes drier.
claim: Banning umbrellas will make people’s shoes drier.
label: NO

Z: Rain / weather conditions

trap.subtype_name: Rain causes both umbrella use and wet shoes

causal_structure: Rain (Z) is a common cause of both carrying an umbrella (X) and having wet shoes (Y), so the observed association is confounded and does not reflect the effect of do(X).
key_insight: A common cause (rain) explains both umbrella use and wet shoes; umbrellas could be protective conditional on rain.
hidden_timestamp: Is umbrella use primarily determined by whether it is raining?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If rain is the main driver and you do not condition on weather, banning umbrellas won’t dry shoes; it may worsen wetness on rainy days.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If you compare people on equally rainy days with vs without umbrellas, umbrellas may reduce wetness relative to no umbrella.

wise_refusal: Causal attribution is invalid here: the observed association is confounded by weather. Intervening on umbrella use without accounting for rain does not reveal the true effect; the relevant intervention-level flaw is confounding.
gold_rationale: The umbrella–wet shoes association is confounded by rain. People carry umbrellas when it rains, and rain causes wet shoes. Banning umbrellas would not reduce wet shoes and could increase wetness in rainy conditions. The observed association does not justify a causal claim under intervention reasoning.

scenario: A streaming service observes users who enable subtitles are more likely to finish a movie and proposes forcing subtitles on to increase completion, but subtitle use is self-selected (often by context or viewer type).
claim: Forcing subtitles on will increase movie completion rates.
label: NO

Z: Viewer type, motivation, and watching context (e.g., noisy environment, multitasking) confound both subtitle enabling and completion

causal_structure: Viewer motivation and context (Z) influence both the likelihood of enabling subtitles (X) and the probability of completing the movie (Y), so the observed association is confounded and does not reflect the effect of do(X).
key_insight: Self-selection into feature use means observed associations may not generalize to forced interventions.
hidden_timestamp: Is subtitle enabling largely a user choice tied to context or viewer motivation?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: NO — If subtitle enabling reflects self-selection by context or viewer type that also affects completion, the observational correlation does not justify forcing subtitles as a causal lever.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: YES/PARTIAL — If an A/B test forcing subtitles increases completion (overall or for specific segments), then forcing subtitles may causally improve completion for some users.

wise_refusal: Causal attribution is invalid here: the observed association is confounded by viewer motivation and context, so intervening to force subtitles may not have the same effect. This is a classic case of selection bias.
gold_rationale: Subtitles are enabled endogenously and correlate with completion due to context or user type. Without experimental evidence (or strong adjustment), forcing subtitles is not supported as a causal way to increase completion. The observed association is confounded by selection bias.

scenario: A homeowner notices that when they run the dishwasher late at night, their utility app’s *morning* usage estimate looks lower and concludes night dishwashing reduces electricity use.
claim: Running the dishwasher late at night reduces electricity use.
label: NO

X.name: Running the dishwasher late at night

Y.name: Electricity use (as reflected by the morning estimate)

Z: Timing effects in measurement/pricing (e.g., estimation window or off-peak accounting)

causal_structure: Timing (Z) affects both when the dishwasher is run (X) and how the morning electricity usage metric (Y) is computed, so the observed association is due to measurement window artifacts, not a true causal effect.
key_insight: Apparent reductions in usage can result from timing and measurement windows, not actual energy savings.
hidden_timestamp: Is the observed lower morning usage estimate due to a timing artifact (estimation window/off-peak accounting) rather than a true reduction in total electricity use?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the lower usage is due to the morning estimate's measurement window (timing artifact), the claim is not supported—total kWh may be unchanged.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If total daily kWh is actually lower when running at night (with all else equal), then there could be a true reduction, but this is not established by the morning estimate alone.

wise_refusal: Refuse to attribute causality: the lower morning estimate may reflect only a timing artifact, not a real reduction in total electricity use. This is a temporal ambiguity problem.
gold_rationale: The claim is invalid because the observed association is confounded by the timing of measurement: running the dishwasher late at night shifts when usage is recorded, affecting the morning estimate without necessarily reducing total electricity use. Without comparing total daily kWh, the causal effect of night dishwashing is not established.

scenario: A college health center reports students who visit the clinic more often have higher stress scores and concludes clinic visits increase stress, suggesting discouraging non-urgent visits.
claim: Discouraging clinic visits will reduce student stress because visits cause stress.
label: NO

Z: Underlying stress or health needs that prompt clinic visits

causal_structure: Students with higher baseline stress or health needs (Z) are more likely to visit the clinic (X) and also have higher stress scores (Y), creating a spurious association between clinic visits and stress.
key_insight: Clinic use is confounded by underlying need; intervening on visits without addressing baseline stress is misguided.
hidden_timestamp: Are students visiting the clinic because they’re already stressed or have health issues, or does visiting the clinic itself increase stress?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If stress or health needs drive clinic visits, discouraging visits will not reduce stress and may even harm students.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If clinic visits themselves increase stress after controlling for baseline need, then discouraging visits could reduce stress, but this requires experimental evidence.

wise_refusal: Causal attribution is invalid: the observed association is due to selection bias—students with higher stress or health needs are more likely to visit the clinic. Without adjusting for baseline need, we cannot infer that clinic visits cause stress.
gold_rationale: This is a classic case of treatment-seeking selection bias: students with higher stress or health needs both visit the clinic more and have higher stress scores. The association does not mean that clinic visits cause stress, so discouraging visits is not justified without causal evidence.

scenario: Ava missed her morning workout because she overslept. Later she felt sluggish and says: “If I had worked out, I would have felt energetic all day.” The factual X is 'Ava did not work out this morning'; the counterfactual X′ is 'Ava did work out this morning', holding sleep quality/illness fixed.
claim: If Ava had worked out this morning (instead of missing it), she would have felt energetic all day.
label: CONDITIONAL

variables.X: Ava did not work out this morning
Z: Sleep quality/illness affecting both workout and energy

causal_structure: Z (sleep quality/illness) influences both X (workout) and Y (energy). The effect of X on Y depends on the underlying state Z. If Z is poor, even working out may not yield energy all day; if Z is good, a workout could help, but other factors may intervene.
key_insight: Counterfactual claims about energy depend on holding background health fixed and knowing the mechanism linking workouts to energy.
hidden_timestamp: Was Ava's sluggishness mainly due to poor sleep/illness (Z) that would persist even if she worked out, or would a workout have overcome it?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If sluggishness was mainly due to poor sleep/illness that would persist even with a workout, the claim is INVALID—the workout would not guarantee energy all day.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If sleep quality was fine and workouts reliably boost her energy, the claim could be VALID, but 'energetic all day' is still a strong claim due to other possible factors.

wise_refusal: The claim is conditional. Its validity depends on whether sleep/health issues would have prevented energy even with a workout, and on how reliably workouts boost Ava's energy. Without fixing these background factors, the counterfactual cannot be definitively judged.
gold_rationale: This is a structural counterfactual: the effect of working out on all-day energy depends on background health (Z). If Z is poor, working out may not help; if Z is good, it might, but 'all day' is a strong claim. Thus, the counterfactual is conditional on Z and other day factors.

scenario: Noah didn’t buy a concert ticket when it went on sale. Later it sold out and resale prices doubled. Noah says: “If I had bought earlier, I would have saved money.”
claim: If Noah had bought the ticket earlier, he would have saved money.
label: CONDITIONAL

variables.X: Buying the ticket at initial sale
variables.Y: Total money spent to attend the show
Z: Whether Noah would still attend later (and pay resale) vs skip

causal_structure: Buying early reduces cost only relative to worlds where Noah still attends later; the claim depends on that condition. If Noah would have skipped the show after prices rose, then buying earlier would not have saved money compared to spending nothing. Thus, the counterfactual depends on whether attendance is held fixed.
key_insight: ‘Saving money’ requires holding the later attendance decision fixed; otherwise the counterfactual is underspecified.
hidden_timestamp: Did Noah end up attending (e.g., buying resale) or would he have skipped once prices rose?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If Noah would still attend and would otherwise buy at the higher resale price, the claim is VALID—buying earlier would save money.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If Noah would skip the show once prices rose, the claim is INVALID—buying earlier wouldn’t ‘save money’ relative to spending nothing.

wise_refusal: Whether he would have saved money depends on whether he would have attended anyway and paid resale. Without specifying that, the statement is conditional.
gold_rationale: This counterfactual is conditional: buying earlier saves money only compared to a world where Noah still attends and would pay resale. If he would have skipped, earlier purchase would not be ‘saving’ relative to zero spending.

scenario: Sara sent a short, blunt message during an argument. The next day, the other person stopped responding. Sara says: “If I had sent a nicer message, they would still be talking to me.”
claim: If Sara had sent a nicer message, the other person would still be talking to her.
label: CONDITIONAL

variables.X: Message tone (blunt vs. nice)
Z: Underlying relationship state
Prior grievances
Other person's intent to disengage

trap.subtype_name: Outcome depends on unobserved background factors

causal_structure: The underlying relationship state (Z) influences both the tone of Sara's message (X) and the likelihood of continued communication (Y). If Z is poor (e.g., prior grievances or intent to disengage), changing X from blunt to nice may not affect Y. If Z is neutral or positive, X may have a decisive effect on Y.
key_insight: Counterfactual validity depends on whether message tone or deeper relationship issues were the main driver of disengagement.
hidden_timestamp: Was the other person's disengagement predetermined by prior grievances or intent, or was it mainly triggered by Sara's message tone?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the relationship was already unstable and the other person intended to disengage regardless of tone, a nicer message would not have changed the outcome.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the relationship was otherwise stable and the blunt message was the main trigger, a nicer message could plausibly have preserved communication.

wise_refusal: This counterfactual is conditional: without knowing whether message tone or deeper relationship issues were decisive, you cannot assert the claim definitively.
gold_rationale: The counterfactual claim is conditional. If the underlying relationship state or intent to disengage was the main driver, changing the message tone would not affect the outcome. If the blunt message was the decisive trigger, a nicer message could have preserved communication. The scenario lacks enough information to resolve which factor was dominant.

scenario: Ben didn’t ask a question in a meeting because he felt nervous. Later, a decision was made that negatively affected his project. The factual situation is that Ben stayed silent (X). The counterfactual is: if Ben had spoken up (X′), would the decision outcome (Y) have been different, holding all other meeting conditions (Z) fixed?
claim: If Ben had spoken up instead of staying silent, the meeting decision would have changed in his favor.
label: CONDITIONAL

variables.X: Ben staying silent in the meeting
Z: Whether the decision was still malleable (prior commitments / hard constraints)
Stakeholder willingness to be persuaded
All other meeting conditions

causal_structure: Ben's speaking up (X) could affect the decision outcome (Y) only if the decision was still open and stakeholders were persuadable; background conditions Z (such as prior commitments or hard constraints) may block any influence from X to Y.
key_insight: The counterfactual depends on whether the decision was actually open to influence; without this, the claim is conditional.
hidden_timestamp: Was the decision effectively locked in before or outside the meeting due to constraints or prior alignment (Z)?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the decision was still open and Ben’s input would have reached and persuaded key decision-makers, speaking up could have changed the decision.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the decision was constrained or locked in regardless of discussion, speaking up would not have changed the outcome.

wise_refusal: This counterfactual cannot be asserted as valid or invalid without knowing whether the decision was actually malleable and whether Ben’s input would have changed key stakeholders’ beliefs or constraints. The claim is conditional on these background factors.
gold_rationale: The claim is conditional: Ben speaking up could have changed the outcome if the decision was malleable and stakeholders were open to persuasion, but if constraints or prior agreements fixed the decision, the outcome would not change. The validity depends on the status of these background conditions.

scenario: Lina didn’t buy a used car she liked because she wanted to keep looking. Two weeks later, she bought a different car that ended up needing expensive repairs. Lina says: “If I had bought the first car, I wouldn’t have had these repair costs.”
claim: If Lina had bought the first car, she would not have had expensive repair costs.
label: CONDITIONAL

variables.X: Lina buys the first used car instead of the second
Z: Mechanical condition of the first car (latent reliability)

causal_structure: Repair costs (Y) depend on the latent mechanical condition (Z) of the car purchased. The counterfactual claim hinges on whether the first car was more reliable than the second. Since Z is unobserved for the first car, the counterfactual outcome is uncertain.
key_insight: Without knowing the first car’s condition, the counterfactual is conditional on unobserved reliability.
hidden_timestamp: Did the first car have a better mechanical condition than the second? This determines whether repair costs would have been avoided.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the first car was mechanically sound (low Z risk), Lina likely would have avoided expensive repairs.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the first car had similar or worse hidden issues (high Z risk), Lina could still have faced expensive repairs.

wise_refusal: This counterfactual depends on the unknown condition of the first car. Without evidence about its reliability, the claim cannot be asserted as valid or invalid; it is conditional on information not provided.
gold_rationale: The counterfactual claim is conditional: whether Lina would have avoided repair costs depends on the unobserved mechanical condition of the first car. Without inspection or reliability data, the outcome under the counterfactual is indeterminate.

scenario: On Sunday night, Kai feels unusually sad after a tough breakup conversation. That night, Kai writes a gratitude journal entry. By Wednesday, Kai feels better and says: “Gratitude journaling cured my sadness.”
claim: Starting gratitude journaling caused Kai’s sadness to decrease.
label: NO

Y.name: Sadness level over the next few days

Z: An acute breakup-related sadness spike and natural return toward baseline over days

causal_structure: Z → X and Z → Y (an unusually low mood triggers journaling; mood improves as the acute shock fades toward baseline).
key_insight: After an extreme low point, mood often improves with time; one before/after observation can’t attribute recovery to the new habit.
hidden_timestamp: Was journaling started immediately after an unusually intense sadness spike that would likely ease over a few days anyway?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: No—the improvement does not establish that journaling caused the change if the sadness spike was largely driven by a one-time breakup shock that would naturally resolve over days.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: Partial/uncertain—journaling may help, but a stronger design is needed if Kai had persistently elevated sadness for weeks, then began consistent journaling and improved while other factors stayed similar.

wise_refusal: One entry followed by feeling better a few days later isn’t enough evidence. Mood often improves after acute shocks. Track mood over multiple comparable days before/after consistent journaling and consider other concurrent changes (sleep, social support, time).
gold_rationale: This is regression to the mean / acute shock recovery. The initial sadness was unusually high due to a specific event, and improvement over several days can occur without any intervention. A single before/after observation cannot attribute the change to gratitude journaling.

scenario: A community center reports that people who attend weekly meditation classes tend to report higher life satisfaction. A flyer concludes: “Meditation classes increase life satisfaction.”
claim: Attending weekly meditation classes increases life satisfaction.
label: NO

Z: Pre-existing wellness motivation
Baseline mental health
Available free time

causal_structure: Z → X and Z → Y (people who choose to attend differ at baseline in motivation, time, and mental health, which also affect life satisfaction).
key_insight: Baseline differences can create correlations between a program and outcomes even if the program is not the cause.
hidden_timestamp: Were attendees already different before enrollment (more motivated, more free time, different baseline satisfaction/stress)?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: NO — If motivated, wellness-focused people with more free time are more likely to attend, the association does not establish a causal effect of classes.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If attendance were randomly assigned (or waitlist-controlled) and satisfaction rose relative to controls, then the classes could be said to increase life satisfaction.

wise_refusal: The observed correlation could reflect who chooses to attend. To infer causation, compare similar people at baseline (satisfaction, stress, time) with and without classes, or run a randomized/waitlist-controlled study. This is a classic confounding trap.
gold_rationale: Attendance is self-selected: people who are already motivated or have more time (and possibly higher baseline well-being) are more likely to attend and also report higher satisfaction. Without adjustment or random assignment, the flyer’s causal claim is not justified due to confounding.

scenario: After a doctor warns Mina about elevated cholesterol, Mina buys a smartwatch and starts tracking steps. Three months later, Mina’s cholesterol is lower. Mina claims: “Buying a smartwatch lowered my cholesterol. Everyone should buy one.”
claim: Buying a smartwatch will lower cholesterol.
label: NO

Z: Elevated cholesterol / doctor warning (and resulting co-interventions like diet, exercise, meds)

causal_structure: A doctor's warning about high cholesterol (Z) prompts both the adoption of a smartwatch (X) and other cholesterol-lowering actions (diet, exercise, medication) that directly affect cholesterol levels (Y). Thus, Z is a confounder for the relationship between X and Y.
key_insight: The observed improvement may reflect multiple simultaneous changes triggered by the warning, not the smartwatch alone.
hidden_timestamp: Was the smartwatch bought right after a cholesterol warning that also prompted other changes (diet, exercise, meds)?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the smartwatch was bought after a warning that also led to other changes, the improvement cannot be attributed to the smartwatch alone.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the smartwatch was the only change and no other interventions occurred, a causal effect is more plausible but still requires a proper control group.

wise_refusal: Causal attribution is invalid here because the doctor's warning likely triggered multiple changes besides buying a smartwatch. This confounding prevents isolating the effect of the smartwatch under intervention.
gold_rationale: The smartwatch was adopted in response to a cholesterol warning, which also likely prompted other cholesterol-lowering actions. Without controlling for these co-interventions, the observed association does not imply that buying a smartwatch causes lower cholesterol. This is a classic confounding trap.

scenario: A university analyzes only students admitted to a highly selective honors program. Within the honors program, students who report studying the most tend to report lower sleep quality. An administrator concludes: “Studying more causes worse sleep,” and proposes limiting study hours to improve student well-being.
claim: Limiting study hours will improve sleep quality because studying more causes worse sleep.
label: NO

Z: Honors admission (selection into the analyzed sample)

causal_structure: Study hours and sleep quality both influence the likelihood of honors admission (the collider). Conditioning on honors admission can induce a spurious negative association between study hours and sleep quality, even if no causal effect exists.
key_insight: Conditioning on a common effect (collider) can create misleading associations between its causes.
hidden_timestamp: Is the analysis restricted only to students admitted to the honors program (i.e., conditioned on admission)?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the analysis is restricted to honors students, the observed negative association does not imply that increasing study hours will worsen sleep quality.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the analysis includes all students without conditioning on honors admission, the association between study hours and sleep quality may differ and must be causally identified.

wise_refusal: Causal attribution is invalid here because conditioning on honors admission (a collider) can induce a spurious association between study hours and sleep quality. To assess causality, one must avoid conditioning on colliders and use appropriate causal identification strategies.
gold_rationale: The administrator's claim is invalid because analyzing only honors students conditions on a collider (admission), which can create or exaggerate a negative association between study hours and sleep quality. This does not justify an intervention to limit study hours, as the observed association may be entirely due to selection bias.

scenario: A company surveys only customers who registered their product warranty online. Among these registrants, those who report being very satisfied also report using the product more frequently. The company concludes: “Increasing usage causes higher satisfaction,” and considers pushing aggressive reminders to force more usage.
claim: Forcing customers to use the product more will increase satisfaction.
label: NO

Z: Registering the warranty online (selection into the surveyed sample)
Conditioning on a collider (registration depends on both usage and satisfaction)

causal_structure: Product usage frequency and customer satisfaction both influence the likelihood of registering the warranty online. Conditioning the analysis on registrants (Z) induces a spurious association between usage (X) and satisfaction (Y), even if there is no causal effect from usage to satisfaction.
key_insight: Conditioning on a variable affected by both X and Y (a collider) can create a misleading association between X and Y.
hidden_timestamp: Is the analysis restricted to customers who registered the warranty online, excluding non-registrants?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If registration is influenced by both usage and satisfaction and you condition on registration, the observed association does not justify that increasing usage will increase satisfaction.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If you use a representative sample (registrants and non-registrants) or randomize reminders and observe improved satisfaction, only then could you begin to infer causality.

wise_refusal: I cannot attribute a causal effect from usage to satisfaction based on this registrant-only survey, because conditioning on registration induces collider bias and invalidates the intervention claim.
gold_rationale: Surveying only registrants conditions on a collider influenced by both usage and satisfaction, so the observed association doesn’t justify forcing usage to raise satisfaction. The causal effect cannot be inferred without addressing this selection bias.

scenario: Riley starts wearing blue-light-blocking glasses after a week of late-night screen time and headaches. The next week, Riley has fewer headaches and concludes: “Blue-light glasses prevent headaches.”
claim: Wearing blue-light-blocking glasses will reduce headaches.
label: NO

Z: Headache spike during an unusually intense late-night/screen-time week

causal_structure: An extreme headache week (Z) triggers the adoption of blue-light-blocking glasses (X), but headache frequency (Y) would likely regress toward baseline regardless, making the observed improvement potentially spurious.
key_insight: Improvement after an intervention started at a symptom extreme may reflect regression to the mean, not a true causal effect.
hidden_timestamp: Did Riley start using the glasses immediately after an unusually bad headache week (an extreme period)?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the headache week was an outlier and glasses use was triggered by that outlier, the reduction in headaches does not establish that glasses caused fewer headaches.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If Riley held sleep, caffeine, workload, and screen time similar and headaches reliably decreased only on glasses days (crossover/AB), glasses might help, but a controlled comparison is needed to isolate the effect.

wise_refusal: Causal attribution is invalid here: starting the glasses after an extreme headache week creates regression to the mean, not evidence that the glasses caused improvement.
gold_rationale: Riley began using blue-light-blocking glasses after an unusually bad headache week. Symptoms could improve as the extreme period ends, regardless of the intervention. Without a controlled comparison, the causal claim is not supported due to regression to the mean.

scenario: A company assigns new hires to Building A or Building B. Building A has a free on-site healthy cafeteria; Building B does not. After six months, employees in Building A have lower average weight. A manager concludes: “The healthy cafeteria caused weight loss,” and proposes expanding only the cafeteria as the solution.
claim: The healthy cafeteria caused the weight loss among Building A employees.
label: NO

X.name: Working in Building A with a healthy cafeteria

Y.name: Average weight change after six months

Z: Job role, team, or location (driving building assignment) and related lifestyle differences

causal_structure: Job role, team, or location (Z) influences both building assignment (X) and weight change (Y), creating a backdoor path from X to Y that is not blocked by intervention on X alone.
key_insight: Confounding variables like job role or location can make cafeteria access appear causal when the real driver is who gets assigned where.
hidden_timestamp: Is building assignment correlated with roles, teams, or locations that also affect diet, exercise, and weight change?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: NO — If building assignment is correlated with job roles or lifestyle factors, you cannot isolate the cafeteria as the cause.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: YES/PARTIAL — If assignment is random and the only difference is cafeteria access, then cafeteria access could plausibly have a causal effect.

wise_refusal: Causal attribution to the cafeteria is invalid unless you rule out confounding by assignment-related factors; intervention on cafeteria access alone does not account for these backdoor influences.
gold_rationale: If employees are assigned to buildings based on role or location, those factors can influence both cafeteria access and weight-related behaviors. Without blocking that backdoor path, the cafeteria-specific causal claim is not identified. Only a randomized or independent assignment would justify the causal inference.

scenario: After getting a severe migraine on a particularly hot day, Theo starts drinking more water. Over the next two weeks, Theo has no migraines and concludes: “Drinking more water prevents my migraines.”
claim: Drinking more water will prevent Theo’s migraines.
label: NO

Y.name: Migraine occurrence over the next two weeks

Z: Extreme heat/dehydration trigger
Natural fluctuation in migraine frequency

causal_structure: An extreme trigger (like heat) causes both the initial migraine and the increase in water intake; as conditions normalize, migraines may subside naturally, making it appear as if increased water intake caused the improvement.
key_insight: Starting a new habit right after an extreme episode can make natural reversion look like treatment success.
hidden_timestamp: Was the migraine associated with unusual heat or dehydration that did not persist over the next two weeks?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the migraine was triggered by unusual heat/dehydration that did not repeat, the migraine-free period does not prove water prevented migraines.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If migraines were frequent under similar conditions and repeatedly decreased only when hydration increased (tracked over multiple cycles), hydration might help, but controlled tracking is needed.

wise_refusal: Causal attribution is invalid here because regression to the mean and changing triggers can explain the improvement; intervention on water intake alone does not justify the claim.
gold_rationale: A severe migraine during unusual heat can be followed by a quieter period even without increased water. A single before/after episode cannot establish prevention because natural fluctuation and trigger removal can explain the outcome—this is a classic regression to the mean trap.

scenario: A remote worker notices: on days they wear noise-cancelling headphones, they finish more tasks. They conclude: “Noise-cancelling headphones make me more productive,” and tell coworkers to always wear them.
claim: Wearing noise-cancelling headphones will increase productivity.
label: NO

Z: Day-level context (noise level, task type/difficulty, meeting load, urgency)

causal_structure: Day-level context (Z) influences both whether headphones are used (X) and how many tasks get done (Y), so the observed association may be due to confounding rather than a causal effect of headphones.
key_insight: Context-driven adoption of tools confounds observational comparisons and invalidates naive causal claims.
hidden_timestamp: Are headphones more likely to be worn on days with more noise, deeper focus work, or higher urgency?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If headphone use is chosen based on day difficulty, noise, or task mix that also affects completion, the observation does not identify a causal effect of headphones.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If headphone use is randomly assigned or alternated on comparable days and increases tasks completed, headphones could causally improve focus for some work types.

wise_refusal: Causal attribution is invalid because context-driven headphone use confounds the relationship; only a randomized or controlled intervention could justify the claim.
gold_rationale: Headphones may be used when the day’s context differs (noise, focus work, urgency), which also affects productivity. Without exogenous variation in headphone use, you can’t claim they cause higher task completion. The observed association is confounded by day-level context.

scenario: After several weeks of poor sleep, Sam buys blackout curtains. The following week, Sam sleeps better. Sam concludes: “Blackout curtains fix insomnia,” and recommends them as the solution.
claim: Installing blackout curtains will fix insomnia.
label: NO

Y.name: Sleep quality in the following week

Z: Insomnia severity fluctuation and concurrent routine changes (stress, caffeine, bedtime hygiene) prompting the purchase

causal_structure: A period of poor sleep (Z) prompts Sam to install blackout curtains (X), but sleep quality (Y) may improve naturally as the bad stretch ends or due to other routine changes, not necessarily because of the curtains.
key_insight: Intervening during a bad stretch can make natural improvement look like a treatment effect.
hidden_timestamp: Was the blackout curtain intervention initiated during an unusually bad period of sleep that might have improved regardless of the intervention?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If Sam's insomnia fluctuates and other habits changed around the same time, the improvement cannot be attributed to curtains alone.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If Sam tested curtains versus no curtains on comparable nights while holding other factors stable and consistently slept better with curtains, then curtains may help if light was a key trigger.

wise_refusal: Causal attribution is invalid because the observed improvement may reflect regression to the mean and concurrent changes, not the curtains themselves. Controlled comparisons are needed to isolate the effect of curtains.
gold_rationale: This is a classic regression to the mean trap: Sam installed blackout curtains after a particularly bad stretch of sleep, and subsequent improvement may simply reflect natural fluctuation or other routine changes. The claim that curtains 'fix insomnia' is not justified without controlled intervention.

scenario: A driving school analyzes only students who passed the road test. Among passers, those who practiced more hours report making more minor mistakes during lessons. The school concludes: “More practice causes more mistakes,” and suggests students should practice less to avoid errors.
claim: Reducing practice hours will reduce mistakes because practice causes mistakes.
label: NO

Z: Passing the road test (selection variable; collider between practice and mistakes)

causal_structure: Both practice hours and mistake rates influence the probability of passing (the collider). Conditioning on passing induces a spurious association between practice and mistakes, even if no direct causal effect exists.
key_insight: Conditioning on a collider (passing) can create misleading associations between variables that both affect the collider.
hidden_timestamp: Is the analysis restricted to students who passed the road test, excluding those who failed?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: NO — If the analysis is conditioned on passing, the observed association does not reflect the causal effect of practice on mistakes.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If all students are included and mistakes are tracked as practice increases within individuals, the true effect could be revealed, but the original claim remains unsupported by the passers-only data.

wise_refusal: Causal attribution is invalid because conditioning on passing (a collider) induces a spurious association between practice and mistakes. The intervention-level flaw is collider bias (Berkson’s paradox): do not infer causality from passers-only data.
gold_rationale: This is a classic case of collider bias (Berkson’s paradox): restricting analysis to students who pass conditions on a variable influenced by both practice and mistakes, which can induce a spurious negative association. The recommendation to practice less is not causally justified; only an unconditioned or randomized study could reveal the true effect.

scenario: A relationship researcher surveys only couples who have been married for at least 10 years. In this sample, couples who report arguing more also report higher relationship satisfaction. The researcher concludes: “Arguing increases satisfaction,” and suggests couples should argue more to strengthen relationships.
claim: Encouraging couples to argue more will increase relationship satisfaction.
label: NO

Z: Remaining married 10+ years (survivorship/selection into sample)

causal_structure: Both argument frequency (X) and relationship satisfaction (Y) affect the likelihood of remaining married 10+ years (Z). Conditioning on Z (only sampling long-term marriages) induces a spurious association between X and Y that does not reflect the effect of do(X).
key_insight: Survivorship bias can make harmful behaviors appear beneficial by excluding those harmed from the sample.
hidden_timestamp: Are only couples who stayed married 10+ years included, excluding those who divorced earlier?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If high-conflict, low-satisfaction couples are more likely to divorce and thus are excluded, the observed association does not imply arguing causes satisfaction.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If all couples (including those who divorced) are included and constructive conflict is distinguished from destructive, only then can the causal effect be properly evaluated.

wise_refusal: Causal attribution is invalid because the sample only includes couples who survived 10+ years, introducing survivorship bias. The observed association does not justify intervention without accounting for those who divorced.
gold_rationale: This is a classic survivorship bias: by only including couples who remained married for 10+ years, the sample omits couples whose arguing may have reduced satisfaction and led to divorce. Thus, the observed positive association between arguing and satisfaction among survivors does not justify the claim that arguing increases satisfaction for all couples. Intervening to increase arguing could be harmful, as the causal effect is confounded by selection on survivors.

scenario: A friend says: people who use a language-learning app daily tend to become fluent faster. They conclude: “If you install this app, you will become fluent.” But the most motivated learners both use the app more and practice speaking outside the app.
claim: Using the language-learning app daily will cause faster conversational fluency.
label: NO

Z: Learner motivation/commitment is a confounder that affects both app usage and additional outside practice

trap.subtype_name: Motivated learners do more of everything

causal_structure: Learner motivation (Z) causes both frequent app use (X) and faster fluency (Y) via more total practice, so the observed association does not reflect the causal effect of the app alone.
key_insight: Motivation confounds the relationship: motivated learners use the app more and also practice more outside the app.
hidden_timestamp: Do daily app users differ in baseline motivation/commitment compared to non-users?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: NO — If motivation differs and is not controlled, the causal claim about the app alone is not supported.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If learners are matched or randomized on baseline motivation and total practice time, the app's effect could be isolated, but this is not shown in the observational data.

wise_refusal: Causal attribution is invalid because motivation and total practice confound the observed association; only an experiment or proper adjustment could isolate the app's effect.
gold_rationale: Daily app users are likely more motivated and practice more overall, which drives fluency. The observed correlation does not prove the app itself causes faster fluency, as motivation confounds the relationship.

scenario: A school district notices that classes held in rooms with better ventilation have fewer reported colds. The district proposes: “If we install better ventilation, colds will decrease.” But the best-ventilated rooms are also newer, less crowded, and used by teachers who enforce stricter sick policies.
claim: Installing better ventilation will reduce colds in classrooms.
label: NO

Y.name: Number of colds reported in a class

Z: Classroom environment quality (crowding, building condition, teacher policies)

trap.subtype_name: Ventilation correlated with crowding and policies

causal_structure: A confounder (classroom environment quality) affects both ventilation (X) and cold rates (Y), so observed associations may not reflect the true effect of ventilation. Z → X and Z → Y.
key_insight: Correlated classroom factors confound the effect of ventilation on colds; intervention claims require isolating ventilation from other variables.
hidden_timestamp: Are well-ventilated rooms also systematically less crowded/newer or associated with different teacher policies?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: NO — If crowding and policies differ systematically across rooms and are not controlled, the causal claim about ventilation alone is not identified.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If ventilation is upgraded within the same rooms while crowding and policies remain similar (pre/post with controls), the effect of ventilation could be estimated more reliably, but the original observational claim remains invalid.

wise_refusal: Causal attribution is invalid because classroom-level confounders (crowding, building condition, teacher policies) affect both ventilation and cold rates. The intervention claim cannot be justified without isolating ventilation from these confounders.
gold_rationale: The observed association between ventilation and colds may be entirely due to confounding by classroom environment quality. Without controlling for these confounders, intervening on ventilation alone may not yield the expected reduction in colds. The causal claim is invalid under intervention reasoning.

scenario: A creator notices that after a week with unusually low social media engagement, they changed their posting time to mornings. The next week, engagement increased. They conclude: “Posting in the morning increases engagement,” and recommend that schedule to everyone.
claim: Changing posting time to mornings will increase engagement.
label: NO

Z: Unusually low engagement week due to random fluctuation

trap.subtype_name: Schedule change after an unusually bad week

causal_structure: An unusually low engagement week (Z) triggers the schedule change (X), and engagement naturally rebounds (Z → Y), making it appear as if the new posting time caused the improvement.
key_insight: Strategy changes after extreme outcomes can create the illusion of causality due to natural rebound.
hidden_timestamp: Was the posting-time change made immediately after an unusually low-engagement week (an outlier)?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the change was triggered by an outlier low week, the rebound does not prove mornings caused the increase.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If posting times were alternated across comparable weeks and mornings consistently performed better, there may be a true effect, but repeated tests are needed.

wise_refusal: Causal attribution is invalid here because the intervention (changing posting time) was triggered by an extreme low outlier, making regression to the mean a likely explanation for the observed improvement.
gold_rationale: The claim is invalid because the schedule change was prompted by an unusually low week, so any subsequent improvement could be due to regression to the mean rather than a true effect of posting in the morning. Without repeated, controlled comparisons, we cannot infer causality.

scenario: Jules missed a morning flight because of unexpected traffic and long security lines. Factual: Jules left home at the original time and missed the flight. Counterfactual: If Jules had left home 30 minutes earlier, would Jules have made the flight, holding the severity and timing of delays and the boarding cutoff fixed?
claim: If Jules had left 30 minutes earlier instead of the original time, Jules would have made the flight.
label: CONDITIONAL

variables.X: Jules leaves home at the original time
Z: Severity and timing of traffic/security delays
Boarding cutoff time
