causal_structure: Whether leaving 30 minutes earlier would result in making the flight depends on how the delays and boarding cutoff time interact with the new departure time. If the delays are such that leaving earlier avoids the bottleneck, the outcome changes; if not, the outcome stays the same.
key_insight: The counterfactual outcome depends on the timing and severity of delays and the boarding cutoff, making the claim conditional.
hidden_timestamp: Would leaving 30 minutes earlier have changed the realized traffic and security delays enough to reach the gate before boarding closed?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the delays were near-threshold and leaving 30 minutes earlier would place Jules ahead of the security surge and before boarding closed, the claim is VALID—leaving earlier could plausibly make the flight.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If delays were severe (e.g., multi-hour security outage) or boarding closed well before Jules could arrive even with a 30-minute head start, the claim is INVALID—leaving earlier would not be sufficient.

wise_refusal: This counterfactual depends on how delays would have unfolded if Jules left earlier and on the boarding cutoff. Without knowing whether 30 minutes is enough to clear the bottleneck, the claim is conditional.
gold_rationale: The statement is conditional. Leaving earlier can increase the chance of making the flight, but whether 30 minutes is enough depends on the severity and timing of delays and the boarding cutoff. Without that information, you cannot assert the counterfactual as certain.

scenario: Taylor considered buying a stock last year but did not. The stock later increased significantly. The factual situation is that Taylor did not buy the stock. The counterfactual is: if Taylor had bought the stock last year, what would have happened?
claim: If Taylor had bought the stock last year, Taylor would have made a lot of money.
label: CONDITIONAL

variables.X: Taylor buys the stock last year
variables.Y: Taylor makes a lot of money from the stock
Z: Taylor's holding/selling behavior (whether Taylor would have held through volatility and sold after the rise)
Timing of sale
Taylor's risk tolerance

causal_structure: Buying the stock (X) is necessary but not sufficient for profit (Y); profit also depends on Taylor's holding/selling behavior and timing (Z). If Taylor would have held through volatility and sold after the price increase, the profit would occur. If Taylor sold earlier, the profit might not materialize.
key_insight: Counterfactual profit depends on both the act of buying and the subsequent holding/selling decisions.
hidden_timestamp: Would Taylor have held the stock until after the price increase, or would Taylor have sold earlier during volatility?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If Taylor would have held until after the price increase and sold then, the claim is VALID: Taylor would have made a lot of money.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If Taylor would have sold before the price increase (e.g., during volatility), the claim is INVALID: Taylor would not have made a lot of money.

wise_refusal: The counterfactual claim is conditional: it depends on Taylor's holding and selling behavior, which is not specified. Without knowing whether Taylor would have held through volatility and sold after the rise, we cannot definitively say the claim is valid.
gold_rationale: The counterfactual is conditional. If Taylor would have held the stock until after the price increase and sold then, the claim is valid. If Taylor would have sold before the increase, the claim is invalid. The outcome depends on Taylor's unobserved holding/selling behavior.

scenario: On the day of an important afternoon presentation, Morgan skipped lunch and felt unfocused. Morgan says: “If I had eaten lunch, I would have delivered a much better presentation.” The factual world is: Morgan skipped lunch and performed poorly. The counterfactual world is: Morgan eats lunch instead.
claim: If Morgan had eaten lunch, Morgan would have delivered a much better presentation.
label: CONDITIONAL

variables.X: Morgan skipped lunch before the presentation
Z: Stress/anxiety level that day (affecting appetite/decision to eat and performance)
Preparation quality

causal_structure: Stress/anxiety and preparation (Z) influence both the likelihood of skipping lunch (X) and presentation quality (Y). Changing X to 'eating lunch' could improve energy and focus, but if Z (stress/anxiety or poor preparation) is the dominant factor, the outcome Y may not improve much. The counterfactual depends on which cause is primary.
key_insight: The effect of eating lunch on performance is conditional on whether low energy or stress/preparation was the main limiting factor.
hidden_timestamp: Was Morgan’s poor performance primarily due to skipping lunch (low energy), or due to stress/anxiety or poor preparation that would persist even if Morgan ate?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If Morgan's main issue was low energy from skipping lunch, eating lunch could plausibly lead to a much better presentation.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If stress/anxiety or poor preparation was the main cause, eating lunch would not necessarily yield a much better presentation.

wise_refusal: The counterfactual claim is conditional: without knowing whether lunch or stress/preparation was the main factor, we cannot assert that eating lunch would have made the presentation much better.
gold_rationale: This counterfactual is conditional. Eating lunch might improve energy and focus, but performance also depends heavily on stress/anxiety and preparation. Without evidence that lunch was the main limiting factor, the claim cannot be asserted as certain.

scenario: During a tense project thread, Devon replied quickly with a blunt message. The next day, the team lead escalated the issue. The factual X is: Devon replied with a blunt message. The counterfactual X′ is: Devon did not reply at all.
claim: If Devon had not replied, the issue would not have been escalated.
label: CONDITIONAL

variables.X: Devon replied with a blunt message
Z: Issue severity / escalation inevitability (lead intent, deadlines, policy constraints)

causal_structure: Devon's reply (X) could influence escalation (Y) only if the escalation was not already inevitable due to issue severity or the team lead's prior intent (Z). If escalation was predetermined by Z, changing X would not affect Y. If the reply was the decisive trigger, then changing X could change Y.
key_insight: The counterfactual depends on whether escalation was inevitable due to background factors or was triggered by Devon's reply.
hidden_timestamp: Was escalation already likely due to issue severity or the lead’s prior intent, regardless of Devon’s reply?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If escalation was already planned due to severity or deadlines (Z), not replying would not have prevented escalation.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If escalation was triggered specifically by Devon’s blunt reply and the issue was otherwise manageable, not replying could plausibly have prevented escalation.

wise_refusal: This is conditional. Without knowing whether escalation was already likely due to severity or prior decisions, you can’t claim not replying would have prevented it. You’d need evidence that the reply was the main trigger.
gold_rationale: The claim is conditional. If escalation was driven by severity or pre-existing intent, Devon’s reply would not be decisive. Only if the reply directly caused escalation (e.g., by escalating tone) would the counterfactual likely hold.

scenario: When choosing a college major, Pri chose Art History. Years later, Pri feels financially stressed and says: “If I had majored in Computer Science, I would be earning much more now.” The factual world is Pri majored in Art History; the counterfactual is Pri majors in Computer Science instead, with all other background factors (aptitude, persistence, career follow-through) held fixed.
claim: If Pri had majored in Computer Science instead of Art History, Pri would be earning much more now.
label: CONDITIONAL

variables.X: Pri's college major (factual: Art History, counterfactual: Computer Science)
Z: Pri's aptitude for CS
Pri's persistence in completing the CS major
Pri's likelihood of pursuing a CS career path

causal_structure: Majoring in CS could lead to higher earnings, but only if Pri had the aptitude, persistence, and career follow-through to complete the major and enter the CS job market. The counterfactual outcome depends on these background factors, which are not established.
key_insight: Counterfactuals about life choices often hinge on unobserved traits and downstream decisions, making their validity conditional.
hidden_timestamp: Would Pri have had the aptitude, persistence, and interest to complete a CS major and pursue a CS career path under the counterfactual?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If Pri had the aptitude and persistence to complete CS and pursued a CS career, the claim is VALID: Pri would likely be earning much more now.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If Pri lacked the aptitude or did not follow through with a CS career, the claim is INVALID: earnings would not necessarily be higher.

wise_refusal: The claim is conditional on whether Pri would have completed the CS major and entered the CS career pipeline. Without knowing Pri's aptitude and follow-through, the counterfactual cannot be definitively labeled as valid or invalid.
gold_rationale: The counterfactual claim depends on unobserved background factors: Pri's aptitude for CS, persistence in completing the major, and willingness to pursue a CS career. If these conditions are met, higher earnings are plausible; if not, the claim does not hold. Thus, the validity is conditional.

scenario: A gym posts that members who take the “advanced HIIT” class have lower body fat than members who don’t. The post concludes: “HIIT classes reduce body fat.”
claim: Taking the advanced HIIT class reduces body fat.
label: NO

Z: Baseline fitness/motivation (diet discipline, training history)

causal_structure: Motivated/fitter members (Z) are more likely to enroll in advanced HIIT (X) and also tend to have lower body fat (Y), confounding the association.
key_insight: Self-selection into an intense class can explain the association without the class being the cause.
hidden_timestamp: Do HIIT participants differ in baseline fitness, diet habits, or motivation compared to non-participants?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If more motivated/fitter members disproportionately enroll in advanced HIIT, the association is confounded and the causal claim is not justified.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If enrollment were randomized (or matched) and body fat decreased more for HIIT participants, a causal effect would be plausible.

wise_refusal: A correlation between HIIT enrollment and lower body fat can be driven by who chooses HIIT. To infer causality, compare similar members (baseline fitness/diet) or randomize a HIIT trial.
gold_rationale: Advanced HIIT participants are likely already more fit and motivated, with better diet adherence. Without controlling these factors or randomizing class participation, the observed association does not establish that HIIT caused lower body fat.

scenario: A sleep blog reports that among people who consult a sleep specialist, those who take prescription sleep medication report worse sleep quality than those who don’t. The blog concludes: “Sleep medication makes sleep worse.”
claim: Prescription sleep medication makes sleep worse.
label: NO

Z: Baseline insomnia severity (indication) that drives medication decisions and predicts worse sleep

trap.subtype_name: More severe cases are more likely treated

causal_structure: Z → X and Z → Y (worse baseline insomnia leads to medication and also predicts worse sleep outcomes)
key_insight: Treatment is often given to people with worse baseline problems; naive comparisons can wrongly blame the treatment.
hidden_timestamp: Are medication users more severe cases at baseline than non-users among specialist patients?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If medication is more likely prescribed to those with more severe insomnia, the observed association is confounded and does not support a causal claim.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If severity is comparable (or randomized) and medication worsens objective sleep measures, then a causal harm effect could be supported, but that is not shown here.

wise_refusal: Among specialist patients, medication is typically used for harder cases. To judge medication effects, compare people with similar baseline severity or use randomized/within-person crossover evidence. The observed association is confounded by indication bias.
gold_rationale: This is indication bias (a form of confounding): patients prescribed medication likely had worse insomnia at baseline, which predicts poorer reported sleep even after treatment. The association does not show the medication causes worse sleep.

scenario: After a week of unusually high stress at work, Nia starts using a guided-breathing app every evening. The following week is calmer and Nia feels less anxious. Nia claims: “The breathing app reduced my anxiety.”
claim: Using the guided-breathing app reduced Nia’s anxiety.
label: NO

Z: Work stress intensity that week (an outlier week triggering behavior change)

trap.subtype_name: Intervention starts after an extreme stress week

causal_structure: An unusually stressful week (Z) triggers both the adoption of the breathing app (X) and predicts a likely reduction in anxiety (Y) as stress returns to normal, making it appear as if the app caused the improvement.
key_insight: Natural recovery after an extreme event can be mistaken for a treatment effect if interventions are started at outlier moments.
hidden_timestamp: Was the app started immediately after an unusually stressful week that did not persist?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the prior week was an outlier and the following week would have been calmer anyway, the reduction in anxiety is likely due to regression to the mean, not the app.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If Nia alternated app use across comparable weeks (with similar stress levels) and anxiety reliably decreased on app weeks, this would better support a causal effect.

wise_refusal: Causal attribution is invalid here because the observed improvement may simply reflect regression to the mean after an outlier stress week, not the effect of the app. Intervention-level reasoning requires comparable conditions or randomization.
gold_rationale: This is a classic regression-to-the-mean scenario: the intervention (app use) begins after an extreme stress period, and improvement follows as stress returns to normal. Without a proper control or repeated measures, we cannot attribute the change to the app itself.

scenario: A manager notices: teams that use a new project-tracking tool have fewer missed deadlines. The manager proposes mandating the tool for all teams to reduce missed deadlines.
claim: Mandating the project-tracking tool will reduce missed deadlines.
label: NO

Z: Team maturity and management quality (planning discipline, staffing stability)

causal_structure: Team maturity (Z) influences both the likelihood of adopting the tool (X) and the likelihood of missing deadlines (Y), creating a confounding path between X and Y.
key_insight: Correlation between tool use and fewer missed deadlines may be due to underlying team quality, not the tool itself.
hidden_timestamp: Are teams using the tool already more mature (better staffing/planning) than teams not using it?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If mature teams are more likely to adopt the tool and also miss fewer deadlines regardless, mandating the tool will not necessarily reduce missed deadlines.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the tool is rolled out randomly or staggered and deadlines improve after rollout controlling for team trends, a causal effect is plausible.

wise_refusal: We cannot attribute a causal effect to mandating the tool because team maturity confounds the observed association; an intervention-based evaluation is required.
gold_rationale: The observed association between tool use and fewer missed deadlines is confounded by team maturity and management quality. Without randomization or controlling for these confounders, we cannot conclude that mandating the tool will reduce missed deadlines.

scenario: A nutrition influencer says: “People who take ‘detox tea’ report less bloating.” They recommend that everyone drink detox tea to reduce bloating.
claim: Drinking detox tea reduces bloating.
label: NO

Z: Health-conscious 'reset' behaviors (reduced salt/processed foods, increased water, fewer trigger foods) that co-occur with starting detox tea

trap.subtype_name: Tea adoption bundled with diet/hydration changes

causal_structure: A common cause (wellness reset behaviors) drives both tea use and reduced bloating, so intervening on tea alone does not isolate its effect.
key_insight: Bundled lifestyle changes confound the effect of detox tea on bloating.
hidden_timestamp: Did the reduction in bloating occur alongside other diet/hydration changes, or was tea the only change?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If tea adopters also reduce salt/processed foods and increase hydration at the same time, the observed association is confounded and tea alone may not reduce bloating.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If tea is tested against placebo while holding diet/hydration constant and bloating decreases more with tea, then a causal effect is possible.

wise_refusal: Causal attribution is invalid because tea use is confounded with other health behavior changes; intervention on tea alone does not guarantee the same outcome.
gold_rationale: The influencer’s claim is invalid because people who start detox tea often simultaneously change their diet and hydration in ways that reduce bloating. Without isolating tea from these co-interventions, the observed association does not justify a causal effect under intervention reasoning.

scenario: A clinic compares patients who use a new migraine injection to patients who don’t. Injection users report more migraine days. A nurse concludes: “The injection increases migraines, so we should stop using it.”
claim: Using the migraine injection increases migraine frequency.
label: NO

Z: Baseline migraine severity or refractoriness that triggers prescribing the injection

trap.subtype_name: Sicker patients are selected into injection

causal_structure: Baseline severity (Z) influences both the likelihood of receiving the injection (X) and the number of migraine days (Y), so comparing treated and untreated patients without adjustment confounds the effect of the injection.
key_insight: Clinic-based comparisons can make effective treatments look harmful if sicker patients are more likely to receive them.
hidden_timestamp: Is the injection preferentially prescribed to patients with more severe or refractory migraines?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If injections are prescribed mainly to high-severity/refractory patients, the observed association is confounded and does not reflect a causal effect.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If severity is balanced (e.g., in a randomized trial), then a difference in migraine days could reflect a causal effect of the injection.

wise_refusal: Causal attribution is invalid here because selection bias (indication bias) means that sicker patients are more likely to receive the injection; only randomized or well-adjusted studies can justify a causal claim.
gold_rationale: Patients receiving the injection are likely those with more severe or refractory migraines, so the observed association is confounded by baseline severity. Without randomization or strong adjustment, you cannot conclude the injection increases migraines.

scenario: A dating coach looks only at people currently in relationships. Among those in relationships, people who text their partner less frequently report higher relationship satisfaction. The coach concludes: “Text less to be happier,” and sells a program to reduce texting.
claim: Reducing texting frequency increases relationship satisfaction.
label: NO

Z: Being currently in a relationship (selection/survivorship gate)

causal_structure: Texting frequency and relationship satisfaction both affect whether a couple stays together (Z). Conditioning on only current relationships (Z) induces a spurious association between X and Y that does not reflect the true causal effect of texting on satisfaction.
key_insight: Restricting analysis to surviving relationships can create misleading associations that do not generalize to interventions.
hidden_timestamp: Are relationships that ended (possibly due to low texting and low satisfaction) excluded from the dataset?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If low texting contributed to breakups that are excluded from the sample, the observed association is distorted and does not reflect the causal effect.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If you include ended relationships or run an experiment and find less texting improves satisfaction, only then could a causal claim be considered.

wise_refusal: Causal attribution is invalid because the analysis is restricted to current relationships, introducing collider bias. The observed association does not justify intervening to reduce texting.
gold_rationale: This is a classic case of collider bias: by only analyzing couples who are still together, the relationship between texting frequency and satisfaction is distorted. The claim that reducing texting increases satisfaction is not justified by this observational data, as it ignores couples who may have broken up due to low texting and low satisfaction.

scenario: A university offers a free tutoring program. Students who attend tutoring more often have lower grades. An administrator concludes: “Tutoring makes grades worse,” and proposes cutting the program.
claim: Tutoring makes grades worse, so cutting tutoring will improve grades.
label: NO

Z: Baseline academic struggle or prior low performance increases tutoring attendance and predicts lower final grades

causal_structure: Students who are struggling academically (Z) are more likely to attend tutoring (X) and also more likely to have lower grades (Y), creating a spurious association between tutoring and grades.
key_insight: Help-seeking is endogenous; naive attendee vs non-attendee comparisons can make support look harmful.
hidden_timestamp: Do students attend tutoring primarily because they are already struggling academically?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If tutoring is used mostly by students with worse baseline performance, the negative association is due to selection bias and not a causal effect.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If tutoring offers are randomized (or waitlist-based) and recipients improve relative to controls, that would support a causal benefit of tutoring access.

wise_refusal: Causal attribution is invalid here because selection bias means students who seek tutoring are already struggling. The observed association does not reflect the effect of do(tutoring attendance).
gold_rationale: Students who attend tutoring are systematically those with lower baseline performance. The observed correlation does not show tutoring causes lower grades; it reflects selection/indication bias. Only a randomized or properly controlled study can estimate the true causal effect.

scenario: A city launches a bike-lane pilot in neighborhoods that already have high bike usage and strong pro-cycling community groups. After the pilot, bike commuting increases in those neighborhoods. The city claims: “The pilot caused the increase,” and uses it as proof the policy always works.
claim: The bike-lane pilot caused the increase in bike commuting.
label: NO

Z: Pre-existing pro-cycling culture and upward pre-trend (used to choose pilot sites)

trap.subtype_name: Pilot placed where cycling already rising

causal_structure: Neighborhoods with strong pro-cycling culture and rising trends (Z) are more likely to be chosen for the pilot (Z → X) and also more likely to see increases in bike commuting regardless of the pilot (Z → Y), confounding the observed association.
key_insight: Pilot placement is endogenous; success may reflect where the trend was already positive.
hidden_timestamp: Were pilot neighborhoods chosen because they already had high or rising cycling and strong advocates?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If pilot siting was driven by strong pre-trends and advocacy, the observed increase cannot be attributed to the pilot itself.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If a matched control or diff-in-diff analysis shows an additional increase beyond counterfactual trends, a causal effect is plausible but must be estimated against the trend.

wise_refusal: Causal attribution is invalid because the pilot was not randomly assigned; selection bias means observed increases may reflect pre-existing trends, not the intervention.
gold_rationale: Because pilot sites were chosen where cycling was already strong or increasing, post-pilot gains may reflect the existing trajectory rather than the policy’s causal effect. Without a proper counterfactual, the observed association does not justify a causal claim under intervention reasoning.

scenario: A company studies only employees who received a promotion. Among promoted employees, those who worked the most overtime report lower job satisfaction. The company concludes: “Overtime reduces satisfaction,” and proposes banning overtime to improve morale.
claim: Banning overtime will improve job satisfaction because overtime reduces satisfaction.
label: NO

Z: Promotion (conditioning on a selected subgroup)

causal_structure: X → Z ← Y (promotion depends on high effort/performance signals and also correlates with traits tied to satisfaction/engagement; conditioning on Z can induce spurious X–Y association).
key_insight: Within a selected group (promoted employees), relationships between variables can be artifacts of selection.
hidden_timestamp: Is the analysis restricted only to employees who were promoted (conditioning on promotion)?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the analysis is restricted to promoted employees (conditioning on promotion), the observed association between overtime and satisfaction may be spurious due to collider bias.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the analysis includes the full workforce with proper controls, a causal effect of overtime on satisfaction could be estimated, but this promoted-only analysis cannot establish it.

wise_refusal: Causal attribution is invalid here because conditioning on promotion (a collider) can induce spurious associations between overtime and satisfaction. The observed association does not justify banning overtime.
gold_rationale: Restricting to promoted employees conditions on a selection variable influenced by both overtime and satisfaction-related traits. This can induce spurious associations, so the evidence does not justify banning overtime. Proper causal inference requires analyzing the full workforce and avoiding selection on colliders.

scenario: A home-organization brand offers a paid “declutter challenge.” Participants report reduced stress after the program. The brand claims: “Paying for our declutter challenge reduces stress,” and encourages everyone to enroll.
claim: Enrolling in the declutter challenge reduces stress.
label: NO

X.name: Enrolling in the paid declutter challenge

Z: Motivation/readiness to change
Time/resources available to enroll and follow through

causal_structure: Motivation and available resources (Z) influence both the likelihood of enrolling in the program (X) and the ability to reduce stress (Y), creating a spurious association between X and Y that does not reflect a true causal effect of the program.
key_insight: Self-selected testimonials do not establish program causality due to selection bias.
hidden_timestamp: Are enrollees systematically more motivated or have more time/resources than non-enrollees?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If motivation and resources drive both enrollment and stress reduction, the observed association is confounded and does not reflect a causal effect.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If access is randomized and stress decreases more for the treated group, a causal effect is plausible but must be measured with controls.

wise_refusal: Causal attribution is invalid because selection bias means enrollees differ systematically from non-enrollees; only a randomized control can test the program’s true effect.
gold_rationale: People who enroll are self-selected and likely differ in motivation and available time, which also predicts stress reduction. Without a control group, the program’s causal effect is not established.

scenario: An HR team uses ‘badge swipes’ as a measure of office presence. They observe that employees with more badge swipes have higher performance ratings. HR concludes: “Forcing employees to come to the office more will increase performance.”
claim: Forcing employees to come to the office more will increase performance ratings.
label: NO

Z: Role type and evaluation norms (some roles require onsite work and are rated/managed differently)

trap.subtype_name: Role drives both presence and ratings

causal_structure: Role type (Z) influences both office presence (X) and performance ratings (Y), so the observed association between X and Y is confounded by Z.
key_insight: Cross-role correlations between badge swipes and ratings are confounded by job role; intervention on presence alone does not identify a causal effect.
hidden_timestamp: Are high-swipe employees concentrated in roles with different responsibilities and evaluation criteria?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If role type and manager expectations drive both badge swipes and ratings, then increasing badge swipes will not causally increase ratings.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If, within the same role/team, increasing onsite days quasi-randomly increases ratings, then a causal effect is possible, but this requires proper causal testing.

wise_refusal: Refuse to attribute causality: The observed association is confounded by role type and evaluation norms. Without controlling for these, intervening on office presence does not guarantee increased performance ratings.
gold_rationale: Employees with more badge swipes may simply be in roles with different expectations and rating practices. The observed correlation does not show that forcing more office presence will improve performance ratings, because role type confounds both variables.

scenario: A school introduces a new math app only in classrooms where teachers volunteered early for pilots. After the pilot, those classrooms show improved test scores. The district claims: “The app caused the improvement.”
claim: The math app caused improved test scores.
label: NO

X.name: Using the new math app (pilot classrooms)

Z: Teacher enthusiasm/skill and implementation quality (volunteer effect) correlated with pilot participation

causal_structure: Teacher enthusiasm or skill (Z) influences both volunteering for the pilot (X) and student test scores (Y), so the observed association between app use and scores is confounded by Z.
key_insight: Volunteer pilots can conflate app effects with teacher quality and implementation intensity.
hidden_timestamp: Were pilot classrooms chosen via teacher volunteering rather than random assignment?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If volunteer teachers differ in enthusiasm or quality from non-volunteers, the observed improvement cannot be causally attributed to the app.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If rollout is randomized across comparable classrooms and scores improve more with the app, a causal effect is plausible.

wise_refusal: Causal attribution is invalid because teacher volunteering introduces selection bias; the observed association does not reflect the effect of do(using the app).
gold_rationale: Because pilot teachers volunteered, they likely differ systematically in enthusiasm and implementation quality. Score gains cannot be attributed solely to the app without controlled rollout. Selection bias means the observed association does not reflect the true causal effect of the app.

scenario: A personal finance blogger notes that people who automate their savings have higher account balances. The blogger claims: “If you turn on auto-savings, you will build wealth,” and sells a course on setting it up.
claim: Turning on auto-savings will cause higher account balances.
label: NO

Z: Financial discipline and income stability that increase both adoption of auto-savings and account balances

trap.subtype_name: Discipline drives both auto-savings and balances

causal_structure: Discipline and income stability (Z) cause both the likelihood of using auto-savings (X) and higher account balances (Y), so the observed association is confounded.
key_insight: Observed differences in balances may reflect who chooses auto-savings, not the effect of auto-savings itself.
hidden_timestamp: Do auto-savers differ in discipline or income stability compared with non-auto-savers?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If discipline and income stability primarily drive both adoption and balance growth, intervening on auto-savings alone will not replicate the observed association.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If a randomized nudge or within-person adoption (controlling for income and spending shocks) increases net savings, then auto-savings may have a true effect.

wise_refusal: Refuse to attribute causality: The observed correlation is confounded by discipline and income stability, so intervening on auto-savings alone does not guarantee higher balances.
gold_rationale: People who turn on auto-savings often already have stable income and disciplined budgeting—factors that also predict higher balances. Without a causal design, the claim that auto-savings causes higher balances is not established because the association is confounded.

scenario: A hospital uses ambulance arrival as an ‘instrument’ for receiving a certain rapid-treatment pathway. They find patients who arrive by ambulance and receive rapid treatment have better outcomes, and conclude: “Rapid treatment caused better outcomes.” But arriving by ambulance can also directly reflect severity and faster triage beyond the pathway.
claim: The rapid-treatment pathway caused better outcomes because ambulance arrivals do better.
label: NO

Z: Ambulance arrival reflects both severity and can change care via other channels (triage priority, pre-hospital care)
Ambulance arrival is not independent of unmeasured confounders and can affect outcomes directly

trap.subtype_name: Instrument affects outcome through multiple paths / correlates with severity

causal_structure: Ambulance arrival (Z) influences both the likelihood of receiving the rapid-treatment pathway (X) and patient outcomes (Y) directly, violating the exclusion and independence assumptions required for valid instrumental variable inference.
key_insight: Instrumental variable analysis fails if the instrument affects the outcome through channels other than the exposure or is associated with confounders.
hidden_timestamp: Does ambulance arrival affect outcomes through channels other than the pathway (e.g., triage priority, pre-hospital interventions) or correlate with severity?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If ambulance arrival directly changes outcomes or correlates with severity, the instrumental variable assumptions are violated and the causal claim is invalid.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If ambulance arrival is random and only affects outcomes via pathway assignment, instrumental variable analysis could be valid, but this is rarely the case in practice.

wise_refusal: Causal attribution is invalid here because ambulance arrival is not a valid instrument—it both reflects severity and can affect outcomes through multiple channels, violating key intervention-level assumptions.
gold_rationale: The claim is invalid because ambulance arrival is not a valid instrument: it is associated with patient severity and can affect outcomes directly (e.g., through triage or pre-hospital care), so the observed association does not identify the causal effect of the rapid-treatment pathway.

scenario: A company only surveys customers who contacted support. Among support-contact customers, those who received a refund report lower satisfaction than those who did not. The company concludes: “Refunds decrease satisfaction,” and considers limiting refunds.
claim: Limiting refunds will increase satisfaction because refunds decrease satisfaction.
label: NO

Z: Problem/complaint severity among support contacts (more severe issues are more likely to get refunds and also depress satisfaction)

causal_structure: Complaint severity (Z) increases the likelihood of receiving a refund (X) and also lowers satisfaction (Y). Thus, the observed association between refunds and satisfaction is confounded by severity.
key_insight: Comparing only support-contact customers confounds the effect of refunds with complaint severity.
hidden_timestamp: Are refunds more likely issued for the most severe problems (which also predict lower satisfaction)?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If refunds are assigned based on severity and severity also drives satisfaction, the observed association is confounded and limiting refunds will not increase satisfaction.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If refunds are randomly assigned within matched complaint types/severity, and refunds improve satisfaction, then refunds may causally increase satisfaction.

wise_refusal: Causal attribution is invalid here because the observed association is confounded by complaint severity—a selection bias trap. Only an experiment or proper adjustment for severity can justify intervention.
gold_rationale: Refund recipients likely had more severe issues to begin with. Without controlling for complaint severity (or using experiments), the company cannot conclude refunds decrease satisfaction or that limiting refunds would help. The observed association is due to selection bias, not a true causal effect.

scenario: After a string of unusually bad customer reviews, a restaurant changes its menu layout. The next month reviews improve. The owner concludes: “Menu layout caused review improvement,” and recommends the change to other restaurants.
claim: Changing menu layout caused the improvement in reviews.
label: NO

Y.name: Average customer review rating next month

Z: Outlier bad streak (random fluctuation and temporary service issues) that triggered the change and then naturally improved

trap.subtype_name: Change made at an extreme low point

causal_structure: Z → X and Z → Y (extreme low ratings trigger intervention; ratings rebound as noise/temporary issues resolve)
key_insight: Intervening after an unusually bad period often coincides with natural rebound, creating false attribution.
hidden_timestamp: Was the menu change made immediately after an unusually bad streak that would likely regress upward anyway?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the bad streak was driven by temporary issues or noise that resolved and reviews naturally rebounded, the improvement is likely due to regression to the mean, not the menu change.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If repeated A/B tests or staggered rollouts show layout changes consistently increase ratings, then a causal effect could be supported.

wise_refusal: Causal attribution is invalid here: the improvement may simply reflect regression to the mean after an extreme event, not a true effect of the menu change.
gold_rationale: The menu change was implemented right after a period of unusually bad reviews, which are likely to improve naturally due to regression to the mean and resolution of temporary issues. Without controlled testing, the causal claim is unsupported because the observed association does not imply a causal effect under intervention.

scenario: A company observes that employees who attend leadership training have higher promotion rates. The company concludes: “Leadership training causes promotions,” and decides to require the training for anyone who wants to be promoted.
claim: Requiring leadership training will cause higher promotion rates.
label: NO

Z: High-potential identification and manager sponsorship (who is nominated/encouraged to attend training)

causal_structure: Sponsorship or high-potential status (Z) causes both attending leadership training (X) and higher promotion rates (Y), so the observed association is confounded by selection bias.
key_insight: Training participation can be a marker of sponsorship, not a driver of promotion.
hidden_timestamp: Are trainees nominated as high-potential employees rather than selected randomly?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If sponsorship/high-potential status drives both training attendance and promotions, requiring training will not itself increase promotions.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If training is randomly offered within comparable groups and increases promotions holding sponsorship constant, then training could have a causal effect.

wise_refusal: Causal attribution is invalid because selection bias means training attendance is not exogenous; the observed association does not imply that requiring training will cause promotions.
gold_rationale: Employees sent to leadership training are often already sponsored or identified as high-potential, which independently increases promotion odds. Therefore, requiring training based on this correlation does not establish it will cause promotions, as the association is confounded by selection bias.

scenario: A hospital compares people who got a ‘priority bed assignment’ to those who did not. People with priority beds have higher survival. The hospital claims: “Priority bed assignment saves lives,” and wants to expand it. But priority beds are given to patients who arrive earlier and have certain characteristics; staffing levels vary by shift.
claim: Expanding priority bed assignment will save lives.
label: NO

Z: Arrival time, shift staffing, and triage pathway differences that affect both bed assignment and survival

trap.subtype_name: Bed assignment correlated with staffing and triage conditions

causal_structure: Shift staffing, arrival time, and triage pathway (Z) influence both who receives a priority bed (X) and patient survival (Y), creating confounding. The observed association between X and Y does not reflect the effect of do(X) because Z is not controlled.
key_insight: Operational confounders like staffing and triage can create spurious associations between policy and outcomes.
hidden_timestamp: Are priority beds assigned based on factors (like arrival time, staffing, or triage) that also affect survival?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If priority beds are assigned based on arrival time, staffing, or triage factors that also affect survival, expanding priority beds may not improve survival because the observed association is confounded.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If priority beds are assigned randomly and survival improves, then a causal effect is plausible, but this is not established by the current observational data.

wise_refusal: Causal attribution is invalid because operational confounding (shift, triage, staffing) means do(X) does not equal observed X; intervention-level inference requires designs that isolate bed assignment from these confounders.
gold_rationale: The claim is invalid because priority bed assignment is confounded with arrival time, staffing, and triage conditions that also affect survival. Without isolating bed assignment from these operational confounders, the observed association cannot be interpreted causally. Only a design that breaks this confounding (e.g., randomization or natural experiment) could justify the claim.

scenario: A researcher studies only people who completed a 12-week running plan. Among completers, those who ran the most miles report more knee pain. The researcher concludes: “Running causes knee pain,” and recommends reducing mileage for everyone.
claim: Reducing running mileage will reduce knee pain because running causes knee pain.
label: NO

Z: Completing the 12-week plan (conditioning on completion / attrition gate)

causal_structure: X → Z ← Y (completion depends on both running mileage tolerance and pain/injury; conditioning on Z induces a spurious association between X and Y among survivors).
key_insight: Completer-only analyses can hide dropouts due to pain and distort relationships among survivors.
hidden_timestamp: Were participants with high pain more likely to drop out and thus excluded from analysis?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If completion depends on both mileage tolerance and pain (and analysis conditions on completion), the observed association between running mileage and knee pain among completers is likely biased and does not reflect the true causal effect.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If all participants are included and attrition is properly modeled or randomized, the causal effect of running mileage on knee pain can be estimated more accurately.

wise_refusal: Causal attribution is invalid because the analysis conditions on completion, a collider, which can induce spurious associations. Proper causal inference requires including all participants and accounting for attrition.
gold_rationale: Because the analysis only includes those who completed the plan, it likely excludes people who dropped out due to pain. Conditioning on completion (a collider) can distort the relationship between running mileage and knee pain, so the recommendation to reduce mileage for everyone is not supported by the observed data.

scenario: On a day Pat felt unusually tired, Pat skipped the gym. Later that day, Pat felt guilty and said: “If I had gone to the gym, I would have had more energy afterward.”
claim: If Pat had gone to the gym, Pat would have had more energy afterward.
label: CONDITIONAL

variables.X: Going to the gym that day
Z: Cause of fatigue that day (illness, sleep debt, acute stress) which would persist across the counterfactual and also influenced skipping

trap.subtype_name: Effect depends on why Pat was tired

causal_structure: Z affects both X and Y; X may affect Y for some, but the counterfactual hinges on the dominant fatigue mechanism.
key_insight: The same fatigue cause that drove skipping may also limit any energy boost from exercise, making the counterfactual conditional.
hidden_timestamp: Was Pat’s fatigue due to a cause (illness/severe sleep debt) that would keep energy low regardless of going?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If Pat’s fatigue was mild and exercise reliably boosts Pat’s energy/mood, going could plausibly increase short-term energy via arousal/mood mechanisms.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If Pat was sick or severely sleep-deprived such that energy would stay low regardless, changing X would not reliably change Y.

wise_refusal: This depends on why Pat was tired. Exercise can boost energy for some situations, but not when illness or severe sleep debt is the main driver.
gold_rationale: The counterfactual is conditional: going to the gym might increase energy via mood/arousal, but if fatigue was driven by illness or severe sleep debt, energy would likely remain low. Without knowing Z, the claim isn’t determinate.

scenario: Alex sent a job application two days before the deadline and got rejected. The counterfactual is: If Alex had applied earlier (e.g., a week before the deadline instead of two days before), would the outcome have been different?
claim: If Alex had applied earlier, Alex would have gotten an interview.
label: CONDITIONAL

variables.X: Alex applied two days before the deadline.
Z: Hiring process dynamics (rolling vs batch review, interview slots filling)
Application competitiveness relative to the cutoff

trap.subtype_name: Outcome depends on review policy and near-threshold competitiveness

causal_structure: Whether applying earlier would have changed the outcome depends on if the employer used rolling review (where slots fill as applications arrive) and if Alex's application was competitive enough to be near the interview threshold. If both are true, earlier submission could have resulted in an interview. If review was batched or Alex was not competitive, timing would not matter.
key_insight: Timing only matters if the review process is rolling and the application is near the threshold; otherwise, earlier submission would not change the outcome.
hidden_timestamp: Was the employer using rolling review with slots filling early, and was Alex's application near the interview threshold?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the employer used rolling review and Alex was near the threshold, applying earlier could have resulted in an interview.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the employer used batch review or Alex was not competitive, applying earlier would not have changed the outcome.

wise_refusal: The counterfactual depends on unobserved factors: the review process and Alex's competitiveness. Without knowing these, the claim is conditional.
gold_rationale: The claim is conditional. If the employer used rolling review and Alex was near the cutoff, applying earlier could have resulted in an interview. If review was batched or Alex was not competitive, timing would not have changed the outcome.

scenario: During a dinner argument, Casey raised their voice and the conversation escalated. Later Casey says: “If I had stayed calm, we would have resolved the disagreement peacefully.” The factual world is Casey raising their voice; the counterfactual is Casey staying calm.
claim: If Casey had stayed calm instead of raising their voice, the disagreement would have been resolved peacefully.
label: CONDITIONAL

variables.X: Casey raising their voice during the argument
Z: Partner’s emotional state
Underlying issue severity

causal_structure: Casey's calmness (X) can influence whether the disagreement is resolved peacefully (Y), but the outcome also depends on background factors (Z) such as the partner’s emotional state and the severity of the underlying issue. If Z is favorable, X' (staying calm) could plausibly lead to Y; if Z is unfavorable, X' may not be sufficient.
key_insight: Whether Casey's calmness would have changed the outcome depends on the partner's state and the issue's severity.
hidden_timestamp: Would the partner have remained escalated due to their own emotional state or issue severity regardless of Casey’s calmness?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the partner was receptive and Casey’s raised voice was the main trigger for escalation, staying calm could plausibly prevent escalation and enable peaceful resolution.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the partner was already escalated or the issue was severe enough to escalate regardless, Casey’s calmness may not have changed the outcome.

wise_refusal: The counterfactual is conditional: whether staying calm would have led to a peaceful resolution depends on the partner’s emotional state and the issue’s severity.
gold_rationale: The counterfactual is conditional. Calm behavior can reduce escalation risk, but peaceful resolution depends on the partner’s emotional state and the underlying issue severity. Without those details, it cannot be asserted as certain.

scenario: Jordan bought a used car and later faced expensive repairs. Jordan says: “If I had paid for a pre-purchase inspection, I would not have had these repair costs.” The factual X is: Jordan did NOT pay for a pre-purchase inspection. The counterfactual X′ is: Jordan DID pay for a pre-purchase inspection.
claim: If Jordan had paid for a pre-purchase inspection (X′), Jordan would not have had these repair costs (Y).
label: CONDITIONAL

variables.X: Jordan did NOT pay for a pre-purchase inspection
Z: Whether the defect was detectable during a standard inspection
Whether Jordan would have walked away or negotiated based on inspection results

causal_structure: Paying for an inspection (X′) only prevents repair costs (Y) if the defect was detectable and Jordan would have changed their decision based on the inspection (Z). If the defect was not detectable or Jordan would have bought the car anyway, the outcome would not change.
key_insight: The counterfactual depends on both the detectability of the defect and Jordan's willingness to act on inspection results.
hidden_timestamp: Was the defect detectable in a standard inspection, and would Jordan have declined the car or negotiated repair coverage if it was found?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the defect was detectable and Jordan would have walked away or negotiated, the inspection would have prevented the repair costs.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the defect was not detectable or Jordan would have bought the car anyway, the inspection would not have prevented the repair costs.

wise_refusal: This counterfactual is conditional on whether the defect was detectable and whether Jordan would have acted on the inspection results. Inspections reduce risk, but do not guarantee avoidance of repair costs.
gold_rationale: The claim is conditional. A pre-purchase inspection can reduce repair risk, but only if it would have detected the specific defect and if Jordan would have acted on the information. Without those assumptions, the counterfactual is not certain.

scenario: Lena didn’t attend a friend’s birthday party because of work. Later Lena felt left out and said: “If I had gone, my friendships would be stronger now.” The factual world is Lena not attending; the counterfactual is Lena attending instead.
claim: If Lena had gone to the party (instead of missing it), Lena’s friendships would be stronger now.
label: CONDITIONAL

variables.X: Lena attends the birthday party
Z: Overall relationship investment pattern
Friends’ perceptions over time
Whether the party was a pivotal event or one of many

causal_structure: Lena attending the party (X) could influence the strength of her friendships (Y), but the effect depends on background conditions (Z): whether this party was a pivotal event and the overall pattern of Lena’s engagement with her friends. If the party was uniquely important, attending could have a lasting effect. If friendship strength is determined by repeated interactions, one event may not matter.
key_insight: The impact of attending a single event on friendship strength is conditional on context and broader engagement patterns.
hidden_timestamp: Was this party a rare pivotal event in the friendship group, or just one of many regular gatherings?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the party was a pivotal rare gathering and Lena’s absence changed others’ perceptions, attending could have made her friendships stronger.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If friendships are driven by many interactions and one party would not materially change the trajectory, attending would not have made a difference.

wise_refusal: The counterfactual claim depends on whether the party was pivotal and on Lena’s overall engagement pattern. Friendship strength typically depends on repeated interactions, not just one event.
gold_rationale: The claim is conditional. Attending one party could strengthen friendships if it was a pivotal event, but long-run friendship strength usually depends on broader engagement and reciprocal dynamics. Without knowing the context, the counterfactual cannot be asserted as certainly true or false.

scenario: Mira skipped breakfast and later felt irritable during a morning meeting. Mira says: “If I had eaten breakfast, I wouldn’t have been irritable.”
claim: If Mira had eaten breakfast, Mira would not have been irritable in the meeting.
label: CONDITIONAL

variables.X: Mira eating breakfast
Z: Stable blood sugar / reduced hunger during the morning
Meeting stress or conflict

trap.subtype_name: Depends on which mechanism drove the outcome

causal_structure: Breakfast (X) can stabilize blood sugar and reduce hunger (Z), which may reduce irritability (Y). However, if irritability is driven by meeting stress (Z), breakfast may not help.
key_insight: Whether breakfast would have prevented irritability depends on whether hunger/blood sugar or meeting stress was the main cause.
hidden_timestamp: Was Mira's irritability primarily driven by hunger/blood sugar, or by meeting stress/conflict?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If Mira’s irritability is typically hunger-driven and breakfast would prevent hunger, the counterfactual claim is plausible (VALID).
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If irritability was driven by meeting conflict or stress unrelated to hunger, the counterfactual claim does not hold (INVALID).

wise_refusal: The counterfactual depends on whether hunger/blood sugar was the main driver of irritability. If so, breakfast could have prevented it; if not, breakfast may not have helped. Thus, the claim is conditional.
gold_rationale: This is a mediator-based counterfactual: breakfast would affect irritability through hunger/blood sugar. If hunger was the main cause, the claim holds; if not, it may not. Thus, the label is CONDITIONAL.

scenario: Ravi didn’t practice piano this week and struggled at the lesson. Ravi says: “If I had practiced daily, I would have played the piece smoothly.” The factual world is: Ravi did not practice daily. The counterfactual world is: Ravi practiced daily, with all other background conditions (such as the piece's difficulty and Ravi's practice quality) held fixed.
claim: If Ravi had practiced daily, Ravi would have played the piece smoothly at the lesson.
label: CONDITIONAL

variables.X: Practicing piano daily
variables.Y: Playing the piece smoothly at the lesson
Z: Skill consolidation / muscle memory from repeated practice
Difficulty of the piece
Ravi's practice quality

trap.subtype_name: Depends on which mechanism drove the outcome

causal_structure: Practicing daily (X) increases skill consolidation (Z), which typically improves performance (Y). However, if the main barrier is not addressed by repetition (e.g., a technique flaw or piece difficulty), daily practice may not suffice. Thus, the counterfactual outcome depends on which mechanism is limiting performance.
key_insight: Whether daily practice would have led to smooth playing depends on whether repetition addresses the true cause of Ravi's struggle.
hidden_timestamp: Would daily practice meaningfully improve consolidation given the piece’s difficulty and Ravi’s practice quality, or was the main issue a technique flaw not addressed by repetition?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the main issue was lack of repetition and daily practice would build muscle memory, Ravi would likely have played smoothly.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the main issue was a technique flaw or the piece was too difficult for repetition alone to overcome, daily practice would not have guaranteed smooth playing.

wise_refusal: The counterfactual is conditional: daily practice often improves performance, but if Ravi's struggle was due to a technique flaw or insufficient practice quality, daily practice alone may not have changed the outcome.
gold_rationale: The claim is conditional: daily practice can improve consolidation and performance, but it may not guarantee smooth execution if the problem is technique-specific or the piece is too hard. The validity of the counterfactual depends on which mechanism limited Ravi's performance.

scenario: Sam didn’t set an alarm and overslept, arriving late to work. The counterfactual is: If Sam had set an alarm instead, would Sam have arrived on time?
claim: If Sam had set an alarm, Sam would not have been late.
label: CONDITIONAL

variables.X: Setting an alarm
Z: Sam's tendency to wake up to alarms
Commute time buffer
Likelihood of external delays (traffic, transit)

trap.subtype_name: Outcome depends on whether the mediator (wake response) changes

causal_structure: Setting an alarm (X) may cause Sam to wake earlier (mediator), which in turn affects whether Sam arrives on time (Y). The effect depends on Sam's responsiveness to alarms and other background factors (Z).
key_insight: The counterfactual depends on whether setting an alarm would actually change Sam's wake time and whether other delays would still occur.
hidden_timestamp: Would Sam have reliably woken up to the alarm and had enough buffer time for the commute?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If Sam reliably wakes to alarms and has enough buffer time, setting an alarm would likely prevent lateness.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If Sam often sleeps through alarms or would still face delays (e.g., traffic), setting an alarm would not guarantee arriving on time.

wise_refusal: The counterfactual claim is conditional: it depends on whether Sam would actually wake up to the alarm and whether there were sufficient buffer and no external delays. Without knowing these, both outcomes are plausible.
gold_rationale: This is a mediator-based counterfactual: setting an alarm affects wake time, which affects arriving on time. If Sam would respond to the alarm and have sufficient buffer, the claim holds; otherwise not. The validity is conditional on these background factors.

scenario: A hospital provides discharge checklists. After adopting checklists, readmissions decrease. Staff claim checklists reduce readmissions by improving patient understanding of medications and follow-up.
claim: Discharge checklists reduce readmissions.
label: NO

Z: Improved patient understanding/adherence to post-discharge plan
Implementation quality of checklist (teach-back, comprehension, adherence support)

causal_structure: X → Z → Y (checklists improve understanding/adherence; adherence reduces readmissions). If Z (adherence) does not change, do(X) may not affect Y.
key_insight: Causal effect depends on the mediator; without improved adherence, checklists alone may not reduce readmissions.
hidden_timestamp: Did patient understanding and adherence actually improve (teach-back, follow-up) after checklists?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If checklists are implemented with teach-back and measurably improve adherence, readmissions may decrease.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If checklists become box-checking with no comprehension gains, readmissions will likely not decrease.

wise_refusal: I cannot attribute a causal effect to checklists alone; the intervention's impact depends on whether it actually improves patient understanding and adherence (the mediator). Without evidence of mediator change, the causal claim is invalid.
gold_rationale: The observed association between checklists and readmissions is mediated by patient understanding and adherence. If the mediator does not change, intervening on checklists (do(X)) will not necessarily reduce readmissions. The claim fails intervention-level reasoning because the causal pathway is unverified.

scenario: A runner logs their mile times for 30 days. On days right after an unusually fast mile (X = “great performance day”), the next day’s mile time (Y) is typically slower. The runner concludes: “My body naturally regresses after an unusually good day; one great time doesn’t imply I got permanently faster.”
claim: The pattern of a slower time after an unusually fast day can be explained by regression to the mean rather than a real performance decline caused by the fast day.
label: NO

X.name: An unusually fast mile time (extreme good performance day)

Z: Random day-to-day fluctuation or measurement noise in performance

causal_structure: Z → X and Z → Y (extremes arise from noise; subsequent values are less extreme on average)
key_insight: Conditioning on an extreme observation makes the next observation look like a ‘reversal’ even if nothing causal happened.
hidden_timestamp: Was day-to-day performance noisy enough that extreme days occur by chance?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If performance is highly variable due to noise, the slower next-day time is likely regression to the mean, not a causal effect.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If performance is not noisy and extreme days are rare, a slower next-day time might indicate a true causal effect.

wise_refusal: A slow day after a very fast day doesn’t by itself prove a causal ‘crash’; it often reflects normal variability and regression to the mean.
gold_rationale: Because X is selected as an extreme (unusually fast) outcome of a noisy process, the next-day time Y will typically be closer to the runner’s average even without any causal ‘recovery’ effect. The apparent association is explained by regression to the mean, not a true causal effect of X on Y.

scenario: A student notices they study the most (X) on nights before their hardest exams, and they also feel the most stressed (Y) on those same nights. The student concludes: “Studying more isn’t necessarily causing the stress; the exam difficulty is driving both.”
claim: The correlation between studying more and higher stress can be explained by a common cause (exam difficulty) rather than studying causing stress.
label: NO

X.name: Study time the night before an exam

Y.name: Stress level the night before an exam

Z: Exam difficulty or stakes

trap.subtype_name: Z causes both studying and stress

causal_structure: Exam difficulty (Z) causes both more studying (X) and higher stress (Y), creating a spurious association between X and Y.
key_insight: A common cause can create an association between X and Y even if X does not cause Y.
hidden_timestamp: Does exam difficulty directly influence both study time and stress level?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If exam difficulty does drive both study time and stress, the observed correlation is confounded and not causal.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If exam difficulty does not affect both, then the association might be more plausibly causal, but more evidence is needed.

wise_refusal: Without controlling for exam difficulty (the confounder), you cannot conclude that studying itself causes stress from correlation alone. This is a classic case of confounding.
gold_rationale: The observed association between study time and stress is likely due to confounding by exam difficulty, which increases both. The claim correctly identifies that correlation does not imply causation here, as the common cause (Z) explains the relationship.

scenario: A school district randomly assigns half of its middle schools to adopt a new reading curriculum (X) and keeps the rest on the old curriculum. After one semester, treated schools have higher reading scores (Y). The district concludes the new curriculum improved reading performance, but it is unclear whether all schools implemented the curriculum as intended.
claim: Adopting the new reading curriculum increases reading scores.
label: NO

Z: Implementation fidelity: whether the curriculum was delivered as designed
Student baseline reading ability

causal_structure: Random assignment sets X, but the actual causal pathway to Y depends on whether the curriculum was truly implemented in each school. If implementation fidelity is low, do(X) does not reliably change Y, breaking the intended causal link.
key_insight: A causal claim fails if the intervention is not delivered as intended, regardless of random assignment.
hidden_timestamp: Did every school assigned to the new curriculum actually implement it with full fidelity, or did some deviate from the intended protocol?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If all assigned schools implemented the curriculum exactly as designed, the observed increase in reading scores could be attributed to the curriculum itself.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If some assigned schools did not implement the curriculum as intended, the observed association between curriculum adoption and reading scores cannot be causally attributed to the curriculum.

wise_refusal: I must refuse causal attribution because mechanism failure is possible: without confirming full implementation fidelity, adopting the curriculum does not guarantee higher reading scores under intervention.
gold_rationale: Even with random assignment, the causal effect of the curriculum on reading scores is invalid if the intervention mechanism fails—such as incomplete or incorrect curriculum delivery. This mechanism failure means do(X) does not ensure the intended change in Y, so the observed association may not reflect a true causal effect. The trap is that the causal claim is only valid if the intervention is implemented as designed.

scenario: A company notices that employees enroll in a stress-management program right after an unusually stressful month. In the following month, average stress scores are lower. The HR lead says: “We should not credit the program solely for the drop; some of it is likely regression to the mean.”
claim: The observed stress reduction after employees enroll could partly reflect regression to the mean rather than the program’s causal effect.
label: NO

Z: Temporary stress spike / random fluctuation driving enrollment timing

trap.subtype_name: Enrollment triggered by an extreme period

causal_structure: A temporary spike in stress (Z) causes both program enrollment (X) and a natural decline in stress (Y) the following month, so the observed association between X and Y can arise even if the program has no effect.
key_insight: Regression to the mean can create apparent improvement after interventions triggered by extreme values.
hidden_timestamp: Was enrollment typically prompted by unusually high stress periods?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If enrollment is usually triggered by stress spikes, much of the observed improvement is likely regression to the mean.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If enrollment is random with respect to stress level, observed improvement is more likely due to the program.

wise_refusal: Causal attribution is invalid here because regression to the mean can explain the observed improvement; without a proper control or randomization, we cannot infer the program's true effect.
gold_rationale: When enrollment in the program is prompted by unusually high stress, subsequent reductions in stress can occur even without any program effect, due to regression to the mean. The observed association does not imply a causal effect of the program unless we account for this selection mechanism.

scenario: A city tests a new bike-lane design on a randomly selected set of comparable streets (X). After installation, near-miss incidents (Y) decrease on treated streets compared to untreated streets observed over the same period. The city claims the design improved safety.
claim: Installing the new bike-lane design reduces near-miss incidents.
label: NO

Z: Traffic volume / seasonal cycling patterns
Potential spillover effects (drivers rerouting)

trap.subtype_name: Compare treated vs untreated same time

causal_structure: Randomization and concurrent controls aim to block confounding, but unmeasured spillover effects (such as drivers rerouting from treated to untreated streets) or inconsistent measurement could bias the observed association, so do(X) may not equal the observed effect.
key_insight: Even with randomization and concurrent controls, unmeasured spillover or inconsistent measurement can invalidate causal claims.
hidden_timestamp: Were untreated streets measured during the same period with the same near-miss definition, and could spillover effects bias the comparison?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If untreated streets were measured concurrently and no spillover or measurement bias occurred, the causal claim would be more credible.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If spillover effects or inconsistent measurement exist, the observed association does not reflect the true effect of the bike-lane design.

wise_refusal: Refuse to attribute causality because potential spillover effects and measurement inconsistencies could confound the intervention, violating the assumptions needed for do(X) to equal the observed association (Confounding).
gold_rationale: Although randomization and concurrent controls are strong design features, unmeasured spillover (e.g., drivers rerouting from treated to untreated streets) or inconsistent measurement could bias the results. Therefore, the observed association does not necessarily imply that installing the new bike-lane design causes reduced near-miss incidents under intervention reasoning.

scenario: A clinician is evaluating a new migraine medication (X). They note that patients usually seek treatment right after an unusually severe migraine week. The clinician says: “We should expect symptoms to improve next week even without medication, so we need a control group.”
claim: Starting migraine medication causes migraine severity to improve the next week.
label: NO

Z: Severity spike triggering treatment-seeking (extreme baseline)
Natural symptom fluctuation

causal_structure: An extreme baseline week (Z) increases the chance of starting medication (X) and also predicts natural improvement in symptoms (Y) due to regression to the mean, even if X has no effect.
key_insight: Apparent improvement after starting treatment may simply reflect natural regression to the mean, not a true medication effect.
hidden_timestamp: Do patients typically start medication right after unusually severe weeks?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If patients start medication after a symptom peak, improvement may occur naturally regardless of medication.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If treatment is started randomly, observed improvement is more likely attributable to the medication.

wise_refusal: Causal attribution is invalid here because regression to the mean can explain the observed improvement; a control group or randomization is needed to isolate the medication's effect.
gold_rationale: The observed pre/post improvement after starting migraine medication may be due to regression to the mean, since patients tend to seek treatment after unusually severe weeks. Without a control group, we cannot attribute improvement to the medication itself. The causal claim is invalid under intervention reasoning.

scenario: A teacher wants to know whether tutoring (X) improves math scores (Y). The teacher says: “If I only look at students who stayed in the tutoring program for the full semester (Z = ‘completed tutoring’), I may bias the results because struggling students might drop out.”
claim: Receiving tutoring caused higher end-of-semester math scores, based on only analyzing students who completed the tutoring program.
label: NO

Z: Completing tutoring (staying enrolled)
Unmeasured motivation or baseline difficulty

causal_structure: Conditioning on Z (completion) opens a backdoor path from X to Y through unmeasured factors (U) that affect both completion and math scores, creating selection bias.
key_insight: Analyzing only those who complete a program can introduce selection bias if completion is related to unmeasured factors affecting the outcome.
hidden_timestamp: Do dropout/completion patterns depend on motivation or baseline difficulty that also affects scores?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If completion depends on motivation or baseline ability, the observed effect of tutoring among completers is biased.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If completion is random and unrelated to ability or motivation, selection bias is less likely.

wise_refusal: Causal attribution is invalid here because conditioning on completion introduces selection bias; the observed association among completers does not reflect the true effect of tutoring under intervention.
gold_rationale: Conditioning on students who complete tutoring selects a non-random group, potentially influenced by unmeasured factors like motivation or baseline ability. This selection opens a backdoor path between tutoring and scores, so the observed association among completers does not represent the causal effect of tutoring. The correct approach would analyze all students assigned to tutoring (intent-to-treat) or properly account for dropout mechanisms.

scenario: A gym chain pilots an ‘attendance reminder’ text message (X) by randomly selecting half of new members to receive the messages. After 8 weeks, the treated group attends more sessions (Y). The chain concludes reminders increase attendance.
claim: Sending attendance reminder texts increases gym attendance.
label: NO

Z: Baseline motivation

causal_structure: If baseline motivation affects both likelihood of attending the gym and responsiveness to reminders, but randomization is imperfect or there is noncompliance, confounding remains possible. The observed association may reflect mediation or residual confounding.
key_insight: Randomization only isolates the effect if compliance is perfect and there is no post-randomization bias.
hidden_timestamp: Was there perfect compliance with random assignment, or did motivated members self-select into the reminder group post-randomization?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If compliance was perfect and no selection occurred after randomization, the causal claim is supported.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If motivated members were more likely to receive or respond to reminders despite randomization, the observed effect may be confounded.

wise_refusal: I cannot attribute causality to reminders without knowing whether randomization was strictly enforced and there was no post-assignment selection or compliance bias; intervention-level confounding vs mediation remains unresolved.
gold_rationale: Even with randomization, if there is noncompliance or post-randomization selection (e.g., motivated members are more likely to receive or act on reminders), the observed association may not reflect the true causal effect of reminders. The trap is failing to distinguish between confounding and mediation when randomization is imperfect.

scenario: A homeowner tests whether a new air purifier (X) reduces indoor allergy symptoms (Y). They measure symptoms during a high-pollen week, buy the purifier, then measure again during a lower-pollen week. They say: “This is not a fair test because pollen levels changed.”
claim: Using the new air purifier caused the reduction in allergy symptoms.
label: NO

Z: Outdoor pollen level during measurement week
Timing of measurement (pre/post intervention)

trap.subtype_name: Pollen levels changed between pre and post measurements

causal_structure: Outdoor pollen level (Z) affects allergy symptoms (Y) and varies over time; the naive pre/post comparison mixes the effect of the purifier (X) with changes in pollen (Z), so do(X) is not isolated.
